review_title: It's a CURSE' to work at Deutsche Bank in Cary, NC (RUN AWAY)
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Cary, NC
pros:
Global Financial business experience
Decent salary
Decent benefits
cons:
This DB location in Cary is like an offshore center within US. It's run and controlled by The management in London and New York who care less for people in Cary. Too much blame game, extremely unprofessional and chaotic work environment. They work you like a dog for not that great money. Very very unrealistic expectation. Too much drama to put up with. Extremely high bureaucracy and micro management. They have an Agile process for every project which is extremely stressful. Multiple meetings. Most of them are a waste of time. Too much of process which can get annoying at times. Most people here do not dress well. Doesn't feel like you're working for a big bank. It has a startup feel to it. Some people come to work in jeans, shorts, flip flops on all days.

Even if you have to take a vacation, it's not easy to get out as most projects are regulatory and they have to meet the timelines. 

Very poor middle management. Instead of pumping your Morale higher, some Managers bring your morale down. The Managers make sure that you don't even have a single minute of free time.

I've never seen such a stressful and bad work environment ever in my life. Some people are too rude and direct to work with. This is the worst company that I have ever worked with in my life. 

NEVER NEVER NEVER join this bank in Cary, NC.

job_title: Project Manager in New York, NY
pros: Deutsche Bank is so large that one can easily know where other open and interesting positions are. From what I have seen, it is not too difficult to move between department, which is a plus. Also there are some nice perks, such as 4 months of maternity leave and unlimited sick days through the year. The bank has a number of DBPerks which gives you discounts from airlines to Apple computers. The fact the Bank is truly global gives your the ability to relocate if you want to. The tuition reimbursement policy is pretty good, and there are also plenty of courses offered by the bank.
cons: There is a lot of bureaucracy and there is not standard of "perks" through the bank. Some departments get certain perks, while others don't. Of course, if you work in the bank offices you don't get as many privileges and it always feels like your job is on the line, or that you are a cost or nuisance. The offices in Midtown are pretty ugly and many people dislike the open architecture. Unfortunately, it seems that's the way many banks are going. Also, the secretarial support is the worst, at least in my department. In general it seems that it is nearly impossible to fire low performing employees, which in my opinion brings down the moral of entire departments. That is truly an unfortunate aspect of the Bank. It may be that this limited to my department, but it should not be the case.

The on-site cafe is expensive for what you get. 
Some teams are worked like slaves, especially people here on visas.

Grad program is a total joke. The London experience may be nice but you’ll always be “a grad” to everyone and that isn’t a great title to have years after the program has ended. 
Do yourself a favor and stay far away from DB Cary.

review_title: Great culture, decent pay and recognition
pros:
The pay is great compared with other industries, management seem perfectly willing to send employees on training courses and the teams you work in are usually smart, motivated and on top of what they do.

If you work hard and make sure that your managers recognise it then they will usually do a lot to help you go further. Typically they're more than willing to handover more senior duties to you if you've proven yourself, which helps a lot when it comes to salary reviews.

At least in the IT area I work most people tend to work 9-6pm so the hours are quite good but that may be due to it being a down turn and hence lack of motivation to work for a bonus. However, hours can vary wildly and really depend on the team and business function you are supporting.
cons:
As with all companies there is a lot of protective red tape which is often cumbersome and restraining, this can be very frustrating given that most employees see this as more than just a job and are actively trying to improve the way things work. 

Although the culture is generally very friendly, you'll find its common to sit near someone and not even know their name.

I was told that only the new mgr review counts. So I then asked doesn't HR wonder how someone who has always been a top performer drop in 6 months to a poor performer.  They said they don't.  The writing was on the wall. In Sept 2012 I was informed that my role was being eliminated.

review_title: Conservative and slow....but changes are cropping up everywhere
pros:
The overall benefit plans at DB are very competitive and generous.  Examples include a pension plan as well as 401k matching, 25 days vacation for VPs and above, 20 day for levels below.  Generally people are treated fairly by management and work-life balance is respected by most managers.  

DB also has a very competitive compensation plan, with annual bonuses consisting of a large portion of an employees overall compensation.  Recently management has focused more on career growth and promoting "high talent" individuals, these programs have had mixed results, however the focus is in the right place.  

In summary, DB generally attracts talented driven people who make good colleagues and managers
cons: DB globally has a very hard time managing poor performing staff.  This is generally attributed to European labor laws protecting employees at the detriment of the employer.  However, this does effect staffing decisions in places where the labor laws are less stringent (US, Asia, etc).  For example, in the US there are large groups of former Bankers Trust employees who had been grandfathered in to positions due to the merger who are unqualified for the positions they hold.  However, DB has been very ineffective managing out these people, so they end up becoming a drag on team and group productivity and morale.

Good opportunity if out of a Birmingham uni and haven't got experience, or unaware of what these roles should be paying (which could be half of what they pay in London).
cons:
Salaries average for the region - easy to get other non-IB roles in Brum that pay more than DB.
Limited progression opportunities - small teams, a lot of local hiring so you'll be working with a lot of inexperienced people - people haven't generally moved up from London or moved internationally to the site. 
Major time spent trying to get basics right, working into the evening as time not managed well within the day. You'll be expected to sit there if other people haven't finished and help them. 
VPs not very approachable, and VP/AVPs have large teams to look after, hard to get development from them. They'll also want to hold on to you in their team due to the limited experience around that they can replace you with. VP/AVP could even be very inexperienced, having come from the local market with a non-investment banking background. 
Good regional employer, but not what you'd expect for an IB, if moving with experience from Ldn etc, you might not enjoy it much. 
If you join DB Birmingham, and try to move to London - they'll keep you on your Birmingham salary, very hard to get that changed once in there.

pros: Still relevant in European fixed income markets
cons: No coherent strategy to create a viable long-term business

review_title: Best place to be challenged and learn
pros:
DB gives you an opportunity to learn different commodities.  As a business analyst, I have exposure to natural gas, refined products, power, metals, etc. I've never been bored at my job.  In addition to that, I'm very impressed with the quality of people that they hire here.  While I only have a bachelors and didn't come from a Tier One school, everyone around me either has a Masters, PhD, or come from another investment bank such as Goldman, Credit Suisse, or Barclays.  There are others that came from energy companies such as Chevron, Shell, Exxon, and BP.  

I've worked at several energy companies in the past and I always have been able to keep up.  At DB people here are so smart and experienced that I feel dumb at times.  After only two years working here, I've learned more here than all of other other 3 energy companies that I've worked at
cons: Besides the usually office politics, everyone there are not a lot of cons.  There is definitely work and life balance here.  I've haven't really had to work a lot of over time hours or weekends.  By 4:00, most of the trade floor and back office are gone.  Since

review_title: Can be good, but you need to be careful
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits.  The bank wants people to be happy and productive and tries through many initiatives.  A lot of smart people, but motivation is low. Good work is rewarded.
cons: Very politcal, need to step carefully.  The systems are terrible and the proposed solutions are so large that they end up failing.  Long term goals are routinely overruled by new initiatives from senior management.  There's a lot of talk about communication and making things better for employees, but cost cutting and new regulations routinely trump those initiaves.  It can be hard to make meaningful changes from the trenches.

review_title: Software mass-production factory for Deutsche Bank in Moscow
pros:
- Some of IT projects are engineerengly challenging and widely used in the bank
- competitive salary, especially for higher ranks
- good and nice colleagues
- flexible working hours
- the company has started to spend a lot on IT, especially in recent years
- job security, you can successfully pretend to be working for years
- flexible working hours
- business class transcontinental flights
cons:
- Inefficient management obsessed with maintaining good relations with their bosses no matter what and keeping the status quo
- highly hierarchical management structure with many levels of hierarchy and employees on all levels being supposed to "know their places"
- favoritism and lack of promotion and recognition for the rest
- innovation culture is not there at all, you do what you're told to do and keep your ideas to yourself unless someone higher than you has expressed them already
- no perks, goodies and amenities
- crappy office (this will change in 2011 when they move to a different building)
- high workload on some projects
- overbureacratic and very slow internal processes, like buying the software that you need to do the job, etc.

pros: MNC exposure, Cab facility, Good infra
cons: Long working hrs, Under staffed, routine/boring work, poor pay

review_title: Good start for career, but Deutsche Bank needs to do a lot better
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros:

- Excellent analytics
- Some excellent areas work in, but difficult to identify

- Excellent training opportunities

- Attrition too high

review_title: Potential to be a good place to work
job_title: Technology in City of London, England
pros:
Benefits package
CSR
Name
Internal job mobility is promoted
Global presence, opportunities available to work in most key deutsche bank hubs
cons:
Poor senior management - Severe lack of direction, some are promoted not on merit but on who they know.

Worryingly, there are some senior managers, especially in technology who are protected by senior MD's. This "allows" them to behave in any manner they wish, resulting in a bullying culture and some very talented people leaving the bank.

Difficult Promotion process - Although in technology there is a more structured promotion process, the management in charge are not always the right people to make the right decisions. Promotions should be based on meritocracy and the persons ability to work at that level. I agree that a SME that struggles to work with others is a difficult candidate to promote and justifiaby needs to improve this aspect if they are to be promoted. 
There are many examples of employees who get promoted based on length of service, surely something any tier 1 investment bank should not do if they are to remain competitive.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Cary, NC
pros: Salary, vacation and other benefits.
cons:
In my 15 years of  IT career, I did not work in such a negative and highly political environment. The "power" is concentrated in NY and London and the people who are working there for ages do not want you to succeed. The so called architects or managers do not have idea about the current technologies and are not open to any new idea/suggestion and feel threatened, Most of the managers in NY really treat really bad, yes this is true. The same goes with their preferred vendor who's not ready to share knowledge and would treat you like an enemy...
 The recruiters may promise you many things like green card processing/perks/work from home etc and after joining the company you'd get a shock !.. most of the recruiters are contractors who use companies email id and give you impression that he/she is from HR, do not fall for it.
I know at least 4-5 people who left the company in first 3-6 months that speak about the culture and environment which is very political.

review_title: An organization where the culture is degenerating day by day
pros:
In Asia you get much wider exposure to different areas of the bank as well as diversity of initiatives compared to other banks.
Its a profitable bank (compared to a few others on the street) and one can reasonable monetary payoff at the end of the year
Lots of opportunity to improve and better processes and systems, so a very fertile ground for learning and delivery self-satisfaction.
cons:
Organization culture marked by distinct lack of ownership- people only interested in pushing the ball into someone else's court.
Multiple layers of dead-wood at Director level- who offer nothing in terms of execution or strategy but are only there to "track" progress,
Very little empowerment specially in Asia, senior management tries to control/micro-manage and key decisions taken globally without any consideration of regional views.

review_title: DB TSO is an OK place to start your career. Limited career opportunities and archaic environment. Many bright people
pros: Good entry level opportunity to receive exposure to Operations. It does not qualify as IB by any standards whatsoever. Good benefits. There are many bright people who work there and try to develop careers. Good name recognition but limited to IB community.
cons: It does not qualify as IB by any standards whatsoever. They have very specific processes and clerk-type skills that are non-transferable to another financial institution, i.e. useless. If you are looking to spend the rest of your life in Operations, than this is the way to go... It is next to impossible to get into Front Office from Operations. Management is reluctant to recommend their employees to outside managers to do lateral movements within the company. There is significant amount of office politics and favoritism. Business as usual...

pros: Apart from a good salary, there seems to be nothing worth working for.
cons: The Cary location is largely considered a cost lowering place compared to the UK and New York offices. Hence, all the directions come from largely the UK with some from New York. Positions of authority are also reserved from folks who come from the UK with some for people here in the US. If you move from the UK, then you are in good shape, else you need to be part of a clique. It is not important to deliver results if you are in a clique. Politics and nepotism rule the day. Projects and management can change in a hurry. Most of the projects are maintenance projects with the technologies being rather ancient. The word "scrum" is used a a panacea without really understanding how to execute on it.

review_title: Quality and Quantity need to complement each other
pros:
- Sr. Management have a free hand towards deconstruction
- Management is allowed whomsoever they have worked in the past in place of organically grown resources
- Sr. Management call the shots from disbursement of bonus to hikes to optimum utilization of resources. 
- Managers and below have no say and can be walked on as the sr. management pleases
cons:
- unprofessional attitude of sr. management folks
- HR is distrustful and incompetent at all levels. Business partners are just titles thrown around
- HR is unethical and uncaring towards middle management requests e.g. resource requests are delayed or provided with resources who are ineligible for a profile in spite of JD provided
- HR Training and development has sub-standard material and vendors enlisted for product centric trainings. feedback to all levels of the HR T&D goes unheard
- Cost cutting has given way to second rate technology being employed resorting to system crashes, server imbalances, application license outruns, etc.
- Seating cost cut measures throw processes or teams to force fit operate at a different timezone.
- no group or individual moves to nurture talent. 
- Certain departments have the same person doing Quality due diligence checks as well as operations
- culture and values are farce as certain elements of the sr. mgmt neither walk the talk nor do the base level employees put up any effort to imbibe the same.

pros: Large international presence; pretty willing to move loyalists around the firm. Well known name in financial services - DB has a top 5 presence in pretty much every major investment banking product offering globally. Relatively entrepreneurial and laid back culture compared to other investment banks.
cons:
Focusing on the US, DB's is really punching below its weight. The firm has great potential to be a true top tier player in US IBD given the strength of existing platform, emerging relatively unscathed from the credit crisis, and some very good recent hires. However, strategy seems incoherenet and US firm culture is composed of cliques and groups from other firms, who seem to be prouder of working at [Goldman/Morgan/Lehman/Merrill] and treat legacy DB employees as 2nd rate.

One to watch for the future, but there are better places to be right now.

review_title: Working for such a big brand such as DB gives you an inside look at how big companies function
pros: Again, I was able to see how big companies function. This is what happens when you get to work with a big-brand company. Deutsche Bank's investment banking sector (which functions highly as a team) was very interesting for me to see that it had a highly collaborative effort among the staff.
cons:
The downsides of working at DB is that hours are pretty bad and given that I was working in a different part of the world, the culture didn't seem to quite fit with what was back in Germany.

As an intern, I didn't see DB giving an extra effort to retain its staff for full-time positions. Also it's training program for interns could be improved.

As a senior staff, I would have liked DB to pay more attention to them.

pros: Who knows if there are any
cons: Everything over there is problematic

pros: Diverse, brilliant talent pool, charitable donation matching, lots of vacation days and sick days. Work life balance is OK depending on your department. Lots of extracurricular activities and programs, lots of diversity and employee resource groups. Can be a fun atmosphere, depending on department/colleagues.
cons: Recruitment process is misleading. They promise 20% bonuses to get you to relocate to Jacksonville, then you are given 2% during bonus season. Unacceptable. Promotions are given to those who brown-nose and not necessarily the most competent. No collaboration between departments, people can be very arrogant and unhelpful, forgetting we are all on the same team. Management is quick to point the finger at the peons when things go wrong. The vacation days are great in theory, but they are of no use if you never get approved to take the time off because of the workload. Some departments have no direction or clear vision/strategy. No career path in Jacksonville because most of the roles are operational.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: If there are pros for the firm,  it's few and far between.   The best thing about the New York office is a small pocket of employees who are new to the firm that actually try to make a difference.   While they are a small force,  the frustration increases day by day.   It is a common to say "we're up a creek without a paddle".
cons: Two words can pretty much summarize the firm -  accountability and fragmentation.  The culture,  at least in the NYC office,  is one of political finger pointing which lead to a lack of accountability by mid-level and senior managers.   This lack of accountability even for simple concepts such as  "best practices" is affected by this culture.   This also leads to fragmentation - everyone out for themselves instead of helping to improve the culture and the current state of the firm.

review_title: Good for starting your career or you don't have an university title
job_title: Corporate Implementations Analyst in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Good private pension contributions if you are 30 yrs old or above. Good salary, considered the low complexity of work. Very friendly environment with your pairs. HR team will help you if you want to move to another team or branch.
cons: Your tasks will be very repetitive. Low training is provided because you boss most of the time doesn't know himself the bank's products and the HR don't want to pay for external training. Expect a lot of bureaucracy, which mainly doesn't come from Germany but from your line manager, who will be obsessed about control. He/she will create tasks that are not related to your work just to check on you. The Dublin site is considered bad by other branches all around the world. Hence, colleagues from other branches can treat you very badly. The offices are based in the Eastpoint business park which is impossible to reach. The food from the canteen is low quality and the selection is poor.

job_title: Equity Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: It seems pretty difficult to differentiate most of the larger investment banks from each other, but I believe Deutsche Bank is well respected on the Street.  Salaries are competitive.
cons: Similar to all banks, but also depending on what group you work in, a 40-hour work week is unrealistic.  You get paid well, but you're expected to work long hours to finish the job.  You get 5 weeks of vacation time / personal days, but I don't know anyone who would actually be bold enough to use all the allotted vacation time--face time is much more important.  Similarly, even though the company offers flex time and working from home arrangements, I'm not sure I would be willing to pursue those options for fear of jeopardizing the quality of my bonus.  Lastly, the cubicles are uncomfortably tiny (they are so short they only come up to your neck), so there's not much privacy.

pros:
Pay was better than any other place in the area.

Benefits were really great.
cons:
Senior management is playing the politics game and you are not a part of it. They tell you one thing to your face and turn around and mumble the opposite into their headsets.

Your reviews are also politics-driven and don't have anything to do with your actual performance. Get a bad review, you can't advance for another 2 years.

Work/life balance means zilch if you aren't management. Your managers will happily work from home 3 days a week and take whatever days off they please, but you are out of luck and get talked out of taking off.

DB's"Values" are just its way of making itself feel good, they mean nothing in daily practice.

My specific team's managers lied to us about holiday compensation, in order to cut costs and deceive us into taking less money on holidays we were required to work. 

DB is a sinking ship, don't bother.

review_title: Great on a resume, but major restructuring due to cost cutting measures
job_title: Senior Operations Analyst in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Great resume experience, ability to run projects, multi-functional cross team work, great benefits packages
cons: Very little respect or sympathy for work-life balance. Average work day is 9-11 hours, depending on volume, market circumstances, and time of the year. They will pay you less than industry standard if you're not an AVP or higher. Once you advance to a Senior Analyst role, there is little room for movement as there are not often positions opened above you. Can be difficult to move laterally to another department for a new opportunity - more than once during my time there, the departments underwent a hiring freeze for several months or more and that meant you couldn't move anywhere. VERY fast paced environment - this is not a job where you will have time to deal with many personal matters during the day.

pros: Challenging environment to work. So you build up nerve for unorganised environment.
cons:
1. Systems are not in good shape. There are a lot of systems to learn before u learn process. 
2. Application are out of date. DB is still using SSR.
3. Extra pressure on people managers as there are no team leaders. Managers r expected to do TL plus Manager job.
4. Lot of politics.
5. Performance evaluation is not transparent.
6. Human resources department is not efficient at all.
7. IT dept doesn't know what to do with most of the applications plus they work at a snail's speed to resolve any iT issues.
8. Getting application for my staff was big headache. It used to take 2 to 3 months for an employee to get full access to required applications. Massive pain area.

pros: Policy Is Good, Free Cab Facility
cons:
I am having 10 years of experience and I can say truly that I have seen worst management in Deutsche Bank. People who are at VP position thinks that they are the intelligent people on this earth and never come into the picture if team is facing any issue. They always say We as a team but if there will be anything related to work they will say You.

Some VP here are Technical Architect and they will proudly say that they are Technical Architect but they don't know the penny of anything regarding the project. And will put developer only into KT session, Requirement gathering, Designing part. And will never be seen through out the project lifecycle. Only Developers are responsible for entire project. Not only that they Think developer needs to be multi productivity and multi-role guy. He has to work not only in one project but he has to handle multiple project and also need to work as tester and someday has to work as SL2 guy.

For the first time I have given the review on glass door coz of this situation in my entire career and you can think how worst management is here.

job_title: EXECUTIVE ASSISTANT/PA in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Thank goodness for my coworkers.  I would've gone crazy a long time ago.  An atmosphere like this allows the malcontents to find each other.
cons: This company is so big that EAs are just used to manage calendars, book meetings and submit expense reports.  Before the ban on travel (due to cost cutting measures) I used to get to do that too but no mas as of the past year.  Information is disseminated via gossip, not discussions with managers.  So many long term employees are just milking the teat - "working" from home, hiring consultants to do their job, not being held accountable for little, yet important things, like not responding to emails.  The IT Helpdesk is a disaster because no one actually wants to follow through with anything.  All of the in-house systems are counter intuitive so much so that I think they were designed to eff with people.  The offices are run down and borderline gross - there is always a light bulb out somewhere - and the people in the Jersey City office do not dress professionally (to say the least).  Any office non-EU is treated like a red-headed stepchild and there is an air of superiority wafted over from The Fatherland.

pros: Excellent office space, competitive payrate, good medical insurance
cons:
RTC management team is exclusive club for those who think only about themselves and how to preserve the position and power. Zero chances to be promoted to D-level if you are not member of this club. Double standards, unfair treatment of your contribution. Since RTC management team has only stars in it, bonus pool (which decreases every year) majorily distributed amongst this team.

Russia Technology Center is typical realization of team extension model and every manager coming from UK, US or Germany communicate on the every townhall "do you freaking JIRAs". So the only function RTC management team does is harassing everyone to get JIRAs done by all means on time to satisfy higher-ups abroad. If project is accidentally owned and executed in RTC it usually becomes chaotic and fire-fighting activity. No surprise as Russia Technology Center management destroyed Project Management Community of Practice and let all project managers go to the competitor Bank.

review_title: Great company culture, but tough to climb the ladder...
pros: The company has a ton of opportunities to get involved in employee resource groups (think "clubs", or common interest groups), promotes equality in every aspect, and communication is pretty good from the top down.
cons: It can be tough for internal transfers, raises, or promotions. There is a still a bit of that old school, "good ol' boy", days of Wall Street yore mentality that makes it even tougher for women and/or minorities to feel appreciated, equal,  or valued. With that being said, I do believe the company is TRYING to make it better and becoming more progressive.

review_title: Swing and miss approach to banking
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
Flexible work arrangements
Solid mobile options (dbiOS)
Ability to own huge books of work (because no one else wants them)
cons:
Firm claimed no bonuses would be paid (then paid billions in "retention packages" to certain employees) - we all get to suffer for the sins of a few
Garbage performance compared to peers 
Massively hampered by EU / German-specific regs while American peers eat our lunch

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Deutsche Bank has the potential to be a great place to work.  They offer decent salaries.  Well, I'm sure Senior Management isn't complaining, but it could be a little better on the "lower side of town."  The benefits are also decent, but they do offer an excellent maternity/paternity leave.  For the most part the enviroment is a good solid one.  Most of the employees seem to work well together, but then again I can only speak for my floor/group.  Leadership is good.  Lines of communication are very open.  The individuals in those positions seem competent enough.  Overall, I would give working here a B-.
cons: Stagnant for "lower" end employees.  Promotional opportunities are in the middle of the road.  My biggest qualm is that admins are expected to be admins like we have no brains, but yet you are required to have a Bachelors.

review_title: You have a job..but no growth..
job_title: Vice President in Jersey City, NJ
pros: You will have a job if u put a lot of effort beyond regular hours. Reasonable pay and benefits. Part of a larger firm and brand.
cons:
You are stuck at middle management..you should know the right people to move to senior management...it doesnt matter if u are talented..or work hard or have great ideas and knowledge.

senior management works like a political world rather than a performance and result oriented world.

Middle management and senior management positions are more driven by politics, regionalism (U.K employees get more promotions than U.S employees just because they are the middlemen between germany and U.S..and they dictate the terms) and favoritism...

-In townhalls you hear something and what management  later do is totally different.

It is good to join this firm if you are starting your career. But once you reach middle management, you have few options..being in U.S you are always part of a branch office and your growth is very limited..(that's what i saw in my case and almost anyone i know after spending around 10 years at the firm)

job_title: Director, Risk Officer and Manager in New York, NY
pros:
It all depends on the boss. With the right boss this shop offers a lot. 
I guess my cons are more or less similar to competitors. 
If you swim down the river it is great. If you question the management you are history. 
I was satisfied until I decided to leave as I made enough money to have a happy life. 
I witnessed other who got the boot and where of course unhappy.
cons:
Culture has changed significantly and is the worst I have ever seen. 
Management by fear. Most decisions are not made in the interest of the shareholder. 
I witnessed many illegal transactions and cannot believe that regulators keep their eyes closed although they sit day and night next door in the Wall St office.

review_title: An enjoyable experience in Cary NC
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Cary, NC
pros:
Trying very hard to cultivate an environment and culture that was friendly and exciting to software developers.
Diverse workforce.  There were people from all parts of the world working there, and covering the age and gender spectrum.  Made for a very interesting and fun work environment.
Front line managers were supportive.
Lots of projects, and mobility within the Cary location was encouraged.
Competitive salaries, bonuses and benefits.
cons: In my short time there, it seemed to me as if the software center in Cary was growing quite rapidly, that is, experiencing growing pains.  In the time since I left, I have heard that the culture has changed.  That the banking people have lost a little patience with the process of creating an effective software center, which may have been a result of rapid expansion I witnessed.

pros:
Encouragement of individuals looking to move forward. Open communication about performance on a quarterly basis. Strong emphasis on cooperation throughout the bank. Management is encouraged and attempt to build strong teams with individuals of different skill sets. Communication with other areas of the bank throughout the world. Regularly conducted town hall meetings run including board members.

Four weeks of vacation for associate, AVP and VP level employees. Great health care benefits. In building health centers. Free smoking cessation assistance. 401k retirement plan matching. Manadatory training courses to increase knowledge about the bank, the industry, technological  and interpersonal skills. 100% reimbursement for certifications, undergraduate and graduate degrees, approval provided at the discretion of management.
cons:
If you demonstrate yourself to be knowledgeable and reliable you will be constantly on call. Weekends, midnight, holidays, vacations, none of it will be off limits. Team sizes always too small to effectively manage the load. 

It isn't exactly the best time to work in the investment banking industry.

Your friends will crack lots of Nazi jokes.

review_title: don't relocate with them as a voluntary expat
pros:
work life balance is amazing, especially if you work in Frankfurt. Even in NYC work life balance is better than in London
They tend to get good talent so you will frequently work with bright people and it's a great way to grow.
cons:
Your career is tied to how well your manager likes you. if he packs and leaves, will be hard to advance
biggest downside is that HR isn't honest about important topics when relocating and offer zero assistance to acclimate for dependents. They also tell you that they don't offer full or half expat packages, only voluntary expats at AVP level which is not true
another big downside is their tech stack. They hire a bunch of incompetent cheap indian labor at support which means if you are a developer or business analyst, you will bang your head against the wall alot
indian managers in tech hire indians, despite if candidate is competent or not and have no problem spending thousands sponsoring green cards, it's pretty bad

review_title: Hard working employees held back, while smooth talkers are promoted. Not a meritocracy
pros: Hands on work experience, will learn a lot, entrepreneurial environment, initiative is encouraged, treated like a mature adult unlike other banks, good training opportunities.
cons:
If your manager does not like you on personal level you will not get anywhere careerwise despite doing a lot of good and hard work around the clock. 
No promotions from within, always bring in someone from outside to fill in a title aspired to by employees working towards getting that title. 
Recently a lot of employees and managers from crappy US companies began to arrive to Deutsche turning it into another rotten place with their incompetence and tribal politics. Very sad.
If you are in IT and of wrong national origin you will be treated like dirt and abused despite being smarter then the majority.

review_title: Overall, positive experience at Deutsche Bank.
pros: Deutsche Bank is a good company to work for many reasons.  Their compensation (401K, Time off, flexibility, Medical  benefits) are quite good.  In addition, the atmosphere is quite friendly and relaxed.  During my time at the bank, I made a lot of friends and gained a lot of useful knowledge and experience that I will be able to take with me into my next career.
cons: I personally did not have many negative experiences within the Bank.  The only downside I did witness was that it was difficult to move up to a higher job title.  It normally took years before upper management would promote you.  Instead, the Bank was often content to higher someone outside the company for a position versus promoting from within.

pros:
- Work life balance
- Good benefits (not salary or bonus though)
- The nicest colleagues you can think of who are genuinely nice, helpful sincere people.
cons:
- Politics: people who are favoured by management are "safe" from jobs cut and new roles will be created for them to keep them onshore ie NY, London and Singapore
- Too focused on cost cutting, only aim of management
- Internal mobility is very very rare
- Very bad bonus in operations
- A million applications / systems which are either not functioning as they ought to be after all the massive investment pouring into it. 
- Some of the senior management (MD level) has no clue to what the department they are overseeing is about, thus really easy for them to say move jobs to lower cost locations without thinking of the implications

review_title: A great place to start your career
pros:
Good pay
Excellent benefits
Opportunities to learn about the business of investment banking
They hire really smart, talented people
People for the most part are very nice and fun to work with
There are a variety of interesting products you might work with
cons:
It is extraordinarily political and almost impossible to get ahead by just quietly doing your job.  You have to promote yourself constantly which can be uncomfortable for introverts.
There are some huge egos to contend with in management.  If you make one of them mad, it will not go well for you.
There are constant re-orgs and so management and management initiatives change frequently
Lack of consistancy in process 
Lack of process
No real knowledge management to speak of.  You are told to look at the code and figure out what you need to know.
Heavy bureaucracy means it takes a long time to do anything.  The hiring process takes months.
There is a stated initiative aimed at getting rid of the more experienced employees and hiring new graduates and people early in their careers.

review_title: There are better places to work
job_title: Vice President in City of London, England
pros:
Global brand recognised by clients and investors facilitating winning mandates over competitors
Safe pair of hands in turbulent markets especially Europe
Prestige
Good learning ground for new starters
cons:
Not a great corporate culture. Way too much bureaucracy. 
Too many weak managers and mediocre senior people
This bank is NOT a meritocracy so if you are mid level and bright it will be years before you are either promoted or properly remunerated. T/O of star staff quite high at present.
Compensation and bonus pretty poor by market standards

review_title: After 1 year at DB Global Technology
pros: Good salaries, flexible working hours, 4 days work from home / month, the chance to practice your English a lot because most of the teams are spread across many countries.
cons: Not a professional place to work, no procedures, chaotic projects without a clear scope, the software development process very, very slow, promotions based on friendship, no bonuses. They hire hundreds of persons without a real purpose, just to achieve a number of employees in the Bucharest office. It's possible to wait one month for the station installation. The internal communication tool is monitored. Internet access restricted. If you want to connect to yahoo mail, gmail, facebook etc you must take the laptop and connect to different wi-fi. People spend a loooooot of time in calls without scope, purpose and conclusion. Eventually they schedule another 3 other calls to clarify nothing finally.

review_title: Great people but has the issues of a badly managed large corporation
pros:
Purely depends on your team, your manager sets the tone and can either make your experience great or not want to come in.

Easy to build a network across countries and divisions.

Front office are very friendly but this varies by desk.
cons:
If you're a new hire you're fine, Deutsche does not keep salary at market rate so does not rewards loyalty.

There is high turnover in finance and don't be surprised if your team is 90% contractors.

People are hired without the right skill set on much higher than they should be.

Dependent on division some senior management see you purely as an asset and not a person.

The systems are horrendous as highlighted in the press.

There are not enough junior staff coming through the ranks which means you may spend more time doing menial tasks.

pros: Parent company is a great brand and good company overall to work for. Very large and global institution so there are opportunities to interact with lots of people from all walks of life.
cons: With so much change in the last several years, the business has been a hard place to work. I never truly felt like we were on an up swing during my time there. Leadership during this time was largely people who grew up in investment banking which made it frustrating at times. The business went through a potential sale and finally an internal merger with the wealth management business a couple years back and has a short timeline to turn the businesses around. Morale was low and fear was high when I was there. The business was very top heavy and cliquish which made it difficult for what little junior talent we had left to move up.

review_title: Employer of last resort. Consider another industry.
pros: Exposure to many smart people. Fast computer. Good work from home flexibility. The time off policy, if you can use it, is generous. The resume line is nice too, for now. Very smart people are attracted to the DB brand so you get to work with them for a few months or a year or two before they leave, or until you do.
cons: Soft compensation. Tough industry. Unsustainable employment strategy. Lack of strategic direction. Ineffective HR. Lack of expertise: blind leading the blind. Confrontational behaviors, occasional bullying due to competitive rating system. (quiet people with alot of talent but who aren't aggressive don't really get much justice out of the bell curve rating scale) Promotions get held up due to HR not knowing what they are doing. Good people getting burned up. Napoleonic politics. Weak training. Long arbitrary hours and not due to actual needs, but usually due to bureaucracy and inefficiency. Weak technology implementation and SDLC.

pros: Compensation is ok.. People are nice and hard working for the most part.  DB may be a good way to get your foot into the Investment banking world, but DB isn't a place that you will likely stay.
cons: Management / opportunities for advancement are minimal.  Management is only looking out for themselves - which happens elsewhere too but DB Mgmt is not wise enough to see that treating employees well will pay off by getting loyal, hard working people.  Instead, it's typical to use someone up, and they'll quit.  Then Mgmt has to train someone else to do the job.   Advancement is basically nill - you can only really advance if someone higher than you quits (which does happen fairly often but even so, you aren't guarenteed a promotion - even if you deserve it and are very capable of performing the position.

review_title: Chaotic culture, great people, poor leadership from senior management but improving
pros:
Teamwork and within and accross teams is effective and productive with little no politics getting in the way, very much a one bank, one team attitude.

Senior management appear to have recognised how under invested IT has been for some time and are making many of the right sort of changes to process and people management.  There are lots of signs of improvement but it's slow and painful.
cons:
Lots of carryover from the silos of old where IT would be highly aligned with the business group they cover and not at all with the wider IT direction if one could be said to exist.  Though this is changing it's a big culture shift.

Base salaries tend to be lower than competing banks.  Very difficult to be promoted internally - many people appear to leave to take more senior positions outside of the firm.

review_title: Too big and the technology is really outdated
pros:
Truly global bank, diversity
Socially responsible firm that sponsors charities and the arts
Strong balance sheet so jobs are safe in this tough environment
Some great people to work with from all over the world
Pretty laid back atmosphere compared to other investment banks
Easy to get promoted/fast tracked if you work hard, not psycho competitive like other banks, but requires quite a bit of ass kissing
cons:
Technology is very old
Lots of manual processes, very little automation
Extremely political, not a real meritocracy at all
Very slow to make decisions
Tons of red tape:  need all kinds of sign-offs to do even simple/unimportant things
Tons of redundency and segregation of duties makes it hard to get anything done because no one "owns" anything

review_title: A review based on working in a technical environment
pros:
Good culture of mutual respect and support that encourages diversity.
Work / life is well balanced and supported by management.
Sensible and realistic deadlines 
Relatively calm and steady environment  through the financial crisis
cons:
Slow turnaround time in addressing application defects
Inefficient / ineffective change management which often involve approvals from people who lack knowledge in the corresponding systems subject to the change.
Compared to competitors, there is much less career development and also generally there is less traveling opportunities for training.
Culture of blame - too much focus in eliminating outages rather than putting focus on how to improve the test environments and procedures. This has resulted enormous resistance to system improvements and upgrades.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Great pay, benefits. If you do your job, they treat you well.
cons: If you happen to be in an area that is affected by outsourcing (and many of the largest areas were), you should look to work somewhere else. They will not consider strong performers in one area as potentially strong performers in another. Moving around in the company is available to the very few. No matter how well you do in a support function, if "the numbers" don't work for you, you are out. Great to be a stockholder, though. I still have all of my shares. Review process was great financially, terrible professionally (in terms of advancement). They expect you to do your job, and don't consider the fact that you could do something else, something more challenging.

pros:
Regardless of your level of experience in excel your skills will dramatically improve.

Endless coffee
cons:
Beware of any  positions with Reporting in the description or title.  These are old school "sweat shop" positions.

They will tell you that you may have to work more then 40 hours a week in the interview, but in reality you will be expected to work 60-to 80 hours a week including weekends.

You will most likely not be able to take a vacation because we were told that we would need three back-ups for our processes before an approval would be considered.  The turn-over is so high there is no chance of training three back ups. Zero family life balance.

Work is 99% excel driven data mining and data entry.  

If you can see your self sitting behind a computer doing data entry for 10 to 12 hours a day, never seeing the daylight and not being able to take a vacation - this jobs for you.

It is rumored that other departments are better - you will not be able to post for them for at least 2 years (If nothing has changed)

review_title: Steer clear! Bank has major issues
pros: vacation, other benefits and mostly good people.
cons: Where to start! There is a reason that DB is always in the news and that’s because risk, audit, legal and compliance departments have sub-par employees. Legal won’t make a decision on anything and always has to go to outside counsel for something that the in-house counsel should know Management in Germany and London don’t care about US regulations. You can literally tell management that you will have a regulatory problem yet they ignore any pleas for help. No ownership at the senior level! No one can make a decision so nothing gets done which results in those that want to see progress give up eventually and leave.

pros: Brilliant group of people, strong culture and diversity. Mostly everyone had an mba, phD, licenses. Lots of intellectual capital there. 20 vacation days. Small relocation bonus. Some opportunity for working remotely.
cons:
What good are all those days if you can never take them?
They promise 20% bonuses to entice you to relocate there, since there is next to NO talent in Jacksonville.  Then you get a 3% bonus. Don't fall for it.
Disorganized management at the upper levels. No opportunity for advancement. Bosses are indifferent to your efforts. No adequate direction in how to do your job so your efforts are wasted when you do your job and bosses make you start all over due to a new rule. Lots of politics and some annoyingly nosy team members. LOTS of turnover be it doesn't take long for the smarter people to realize morale sucks and leave.

pros: Very good facilities / IT support. It can take some time to be set up initially but once you have been set up, your accounts and profiles can be re-established for a new department quite quickly when moving roles.
cons: Contractors are very much left to their on devices (as you would expect). Getting hold of essential stationary was difficult to start with (I bought in my own folders, paper clips, staples etc). In a project environment there is a great deal of people mobility and turnover so building work relations over time is difficult.

review_title: Only work here (specifically in Cary) if you have no other option left in life
pros: Chill work-life (10-4 kind of job); Generally, people are nice to talk to; active engagement groups
cons:
Every little process is broken (you will experience it in the initial onboarding process itself); worst HR people that you can work with; God bless if you are on a work/ student visa because HR messed up with so many of my international coworkers over these 5 years.

Management (especially Directors) in Cary location have no clue about work. I have seen a few directors who are given the team just for approving absence requests. Some of them work as moral guards whose only job is to make sure people are coming on time and dressing up properly (know one director who commented on someone's attire multiple times)

job_title: Full Stack Software Developer in Pune
pros:
* Sufficient leaves
* WFH
* Work life balance
* If you are lucky, you can get a good manager
cons:
This list is not going to end for sure
* After working for 2.5 yrs you expect smooth exit, but HR is like wait Hold my beer, What is the process again?
* After leaving the bank, I received my full salary for the last month (includes 7 days extra pay), had to call my manager and inform about this and get the thing sorted.
* After 10 days asked them where is my experience certificate, HR team says we just came to know 10 days ago you are leaving, it will take another 10 days, Wow process said someone.
* HR is just a lazy guy, eats money and does nothing.
* Want to work here, go ahead on your own risk, communication team consist of many saints, and hope you never have anything to do with them.
* Are you someone who is interested to speak an conferences, even if its for open source, look away this is not the organization you want to work for.

review_title: Good place to work overall.  Politics a problem like any large bank.
job_title: Associate, Global Markets in New York, NY
pros: Large, global bank with good resources.  Great place to make connections, enhance network, learn, good rotation system when starting out of school.  In US, DB has been investing and growing to upgrade their US reputation to match their reputation in Europe - so that is a good thing to be a part of.  Compensation always seemed fair compared to other banks.  Generally a friendly place to work.  I found most of my coworkers to be helpful and friendly.  Also good work/life balance.  We obviously worked hard, but had the opportunity to have a personal life.  Decent opportunity to move around inside the company.
cons: Politics.  Probably similar to any big company.  The bank is based in Germany and investment bank based in London.  You definitely get that feeling as the executive management do not make many (in some cases any) appearances in NY.

pros: The co-workers that understand the difficulty environment. It is always nice to have good honest people to talk to about the inevitable workplace especially after a team meeting with a manager who is shoving unrealistic metrics down our throats or when they announce that a team member is no longer with the firm.
cons:
Management has unrealistic quality & production standards which creates very frequent firing and quitting of employees. The employee's hard work, dedication or experience doesn't count. Deutsche Bank wants robots, not people. An employee is unable to feel secure as one's work is judged each month. If you made a mistake in the past that will never go away no matter how many positives things you contributed to the company.
Technology needs to be improved tremendously. E-mail set up for new hires will take months and management will still compare your productivity even when you asserted that you did not have the tools yet to be competitive.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Cary, NC
pros: Flexibility, work/life balance, good physical work environment, good at finding smart people, a lot of potential to be a great place to work, some managers work hard at career development for their reports
cons: Management blind to poor development team dynamics, excessive compliance training not applicable to role, changes to bonus compensation and pathetic payouts this year have destroyed morale, computing/development environment too restrictive and hurts productivity

review_title: Good place to launch your career
job_title: Operations Analyst in New York, NY
pros: An excellent place to launch your career. In today's conditions DB is actually doing alright. Good name, good programs for interns and first year grads. If you received your offer after an internship, you'll be placed in a rotational program for a bit. At the end you'll get to decide what group you liked the most. There are plenty of opportunities to advance to middle management.
cons: The atmosphere seems too "political". People in middle management are simply stuck in middle management. Everyone in the upper management tier was either someone they brought in from Goldman or some other bank, or they were from the UK. Very few of the Directors and MD's that I've met and worked with rose up through the ranks within DB itself. I don't know if this is true for all divisions. Makes you think you have no future there beyond being a VP.

pros: Atmosphere is very nice and everyone is very helpful. Lots of benefits that you get right on your start date, no 30 or 60 day waiting period for benefits. Training is abundant. Lots of cultural diversity and nice people to work with.
cons: To be promoted, you must obtain two consecutive years of "Very Good" or better rating. Sometimes, this is not dependent upon your performance, and is decided upon by way upper management on if raises are able to be given or not. You can only try to "transfer" laterally to a position with the same "title" as you, after you have been with the company for a year.

review_title: Entrepreneurial but not a great choice for women or minorities in many business areas
pros: Entrepreneurial environment. Still growth in many businesses. Could really turn around with the right regional management and some hands on leadership
cons: Weak leadership and highly political. Very little diversity in several businesses. Management openly undermine new and upcoming women leaders. Needs to introduce a culture of accountability and consequence from the top down. Still in boys club mode which will continue to get them into trouble as a firm. NY is worse then other regions

review_title: Take the last train to Jacksonville
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Cary, NC
pros:
The new facilities are quite nice and becoming increasingly spacious as people leave.
401k is ok compared to working for the government - though "real" technology companies are better.
Very slow pace may suit many.
Easy to hide if you are lazy.
cons:
Constant state of flux: Several high-profile departures this year leaving a vacuum for indecision and power broking.
No support for the center in wider DB - we are the butt of all jokes from our uk counterparts such as "Cary Cracker Jar", "Cary Creche", "Cary Asylum", "Pulled pork-heads", "DB-Rednecks".  This might be funny to you but we live here
No clear strategy - we answer to the newest whip in town.  The new whip is in Jacksonville so I guess this is where our jobs are going.
Low grade senior management team and dishonest/incompetent HR dept.
Town halls are rubbish - no charisma, no honesty and no action.
Tooling is poor and you cannot use anything not considered standard.

review_title: Great place to work in this market environment.
job_title: Investment Banking Summer Analyst  in New York, NY
pros: DB gives people a great opportunity to work for a global european bank that is growing very fast especially in today's market. After lehman and ML they are definately going to be one of the top banks on wall street. Senior people can be very demanding, don't do investment banking unless you are ready to give up your life. Overall the pay was amazing, never made so much money in my life, there is alot of favortism towards ivy league graduates.  Sometimes the "popular guy" gets respect, recognition, and bonuses over other harder working employees. The office in downtown is a pain if you want to live in village or midtown.
cons: They are starting to cut back on perks and spending, our MD's had to pay for our summer outing out of their own pocket. No car service on weekends.

review_title: A lot of potential, but the center has a serious identity crisis.
job_title: Associate Software Engineer in Cary, NC
pros: The people, on an individual level are good. The benefits package meets or exceeds everything in the area (especially on vacation / sick policy). Work from home allowance seems flexible, but appears to be at the discretion of your direct manager.
cons: I was hired under the impression that this was a "Google like" dev workshop, but every time we have a visitor from New York or London, we have to put on suits and ties to pander to our overlords. This center has zero autonomy, and no control over the products we are "in charge" of delivering.

review_title: World's 5th largest investment bank is worth working for...
pros: The bank cares for its employees, which can be seen by the policies implemented for employee benefit. The environment is chilled out and you arnt scorned for asking any obvious questions. Transport facility saves travel stress and conveyance. Salary is above average compared to local competitors.
cons:
The company being top heavy, one needs to have patience to get promotions. 2 years is average tenure after which you get promoted. 
Less visibility of how your work helps the company's top line or bottom line , thus affecting your motivation to work.

review_title: Decent Company, but bloated with Bureaucracy
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Cary, NC
pros:
Treat their people well if you want to stay in the position you are in.
Decent benefits.
Foster changing jobs so you don't have to be stuck in the same job or with the same team forever.
cons:
Very bureaucratic organization.  Always having management shakeups at the top levels.  Takes forever to get much of anything significant accomplished (6 months to get hardware I can get from Amazon in 2 days??? C'mon guys!)
Very political process in getting promoted... more about who you know and who you can get to recognize you than what you accomplish.  Lots of middle managers more focused on how things are perceived to upper management rather than getting things done.  I saw deliveries that were ready to go being held back so that upper management wouldn't be expecting fast deliveries all the time or to keep from someone higher up the chain from looking good... as I said, very political.

review_title: Joining as an Analyst at Deutsche Bank has been a great learning experience for me right at the start of my career
pros:
Steep learning curve, exposure to different facets of investment banking (in my case Markets).
Great integration with the Global Team including overseas business travel
Interaction with the best talent
cons: Being a large firm sometimes it gets difficult to picture your individual contribution to the global picture, particularly if you are a junior employee in the team. But the regular feedback from global teams, periodic town halls and regular business travel help one understand the big picture better.

job_title: Project Manager/Business Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Nice Cafeteria. Wall Street Location.  Broker/Dealer Trading Desk people were very knowledgeable about the products they trade on a daily basis.
cons: Lack of communication and/or commitment. Rates IT had a very damaged reputation for Not understanding technology, and I couldn't fix that.  Everyone afraid to lose their jobs, and won't commit to understanding in-house technology. No SME-Subject Matter Experts. Back stabbing - will take credit for your work, verbal abuses from those less knowledgeable about technology, etc.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: I liked my team, for the most part. Our division had a great product offering and, had the firm been healthier, business would have been robust.
cons: This is a lengthy list. The firm started to fall into rough shape, seemingly from the moment I got there in 2015. From senior management resignations, to multiple reorgs, the sale of significant business units and many, many fines, the firm fell into disarray very quickly. This doesn't even touch on preexisting deficiencies with technology, controls and, at least in my department, a remarkable lack of work.

pros: Germany's biggest bank and a global leading investment bank. Loads of people from all over the world. Very successful company. Loads of motivated, smart, hardworking people who really get things done.
cons: Deutsche Bank is a bank. If you are a banker or like banks, its perfect. It is a very big organization 100k employees and comes with all the bureaucratic red tape of a large organization. Innovation is one of the articulated core values, but hardly anyone is really innovative, understands what this means. You can build a career if you fit into the framework. If not, even if you do extremely valuable work, you wont progress. Very political organization, risk-taking and decision making not encouraged

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Great salary and Benefits.  The office is really nice.  You rarely see your superior, as they are always traveling or in meetings (that's a huge plus).  No micromanaging!
cons: Administrative and Executive assistants are treated as "old school" secretaries instead of ASSISTANTS.  A Bachelor's Degree in Business means nothing to the executives who you work for.  As far as they are concerned you are there to pour their coffee and order/pick up their lunch, aside from standard administrative duties.  They give the assistants way too many people to assist.  I for one was assisting two department heads and all their staff (about 14 people.)  They gave me a million reasons why I didn't qualify for their tuition reimbursement.

job_title: Product Manager in New York, NY
pros: Your team does not hinder your promotion progress i.e. there is not limit to how many AVPs, VPs can be in a team. Everyone can get promoted if they out perform the other candidates on their level across the bank. They have invested in me to travel and work in a different country at my request
cons: Its a very large bank so getting these done can be draining and some processes are quite archaic.  Focus on career progression can rely heavily on the manager you have

job_title: Vice President in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Cary location is very friendly, good working hours most of the time, reasonably competitive salary, good vacation allowance, some opportunities for travel
cons:
Takes longer to release software than write it. Technology-wise DB is about 5 years behind the competition. Limited opportunities for upward mobility and limited autonomy. All key decisions are made in the London and New York hubs. Very little training provided, very easy to become stuck/trapped in a role.

Infrastructure support is a joke, all support is outsourced and the teams have no accountability and it shows in the level of service they provide.

review_title: Great way to get an initial foot in the door
pros:
-Great work/life balance (depending on department) 

-Intelligent coworkers 

-Decent access to events and company sponsored groups. 

-Laid back office culture  

-Excellent benefits
 
-A recent college grad should absolutely apply, it is a great opportunity to get some professional experience
cons:
-Ineffective upper management 

-Major bureaucracy(Objectives are not achieved)

-Company strategy seems to change every 6 months.(Leads to a severe lack of ability to follow through and lack of vision)

- Very difficult to move up the ladder (If you want to be promoted it's best to work somewhere else and come back as a re-hire)

- Positions constantly being off-shored

- Employee morale very low

- No work/life balance(depending on department, some teams work day in and day out 9 am-11 pm)

- Management not focused on developing employees  

- Easy to get pigeonholed

pros: Deutsche Bank is rated as  "system relevant" or "too big to fail", hence it it is still a player in the market.
cons: Due to massive regulatory requirements the Bank acts more like an agency than a profitable private Bank.  There is too much bureaucracy, many processes are cumbersome. The cost/income ratio is still very low. Reg. cost:  on the one hand there is massive cost pressure and budget cuts every year on IT side, on the other hand -  in particular in investment banking - money is squandered (see recent press news: a big group of investment bankers spent approx. 27.000,-€ each p.a. for travel expenses). Reg. income: too low for many years,  not due to low interest rates on the market only, but mostly by virtue of fines caused by legal disputes caused by Investment Bankers. There is overall a high fluctuation and people are highly de-motivated.

pros: The people are amazing and you will meet alsorts of people from all walks of life. Social events are good generally people are friendly
cons:
Politics! They do not look after the staff at the bottom and hardly no chance of progession unless you really brown nose your manager and anyone above them. Middle management are happy to tell you one thing and do the opposite behind your back. They use the promotions to scale back those who they want to move on and those who they dont want to see do well. Promotions seem to be given on how much you complain not by merit. Doesnt matter how well you do at the end of the year if they dont want you to move up then they wont.

My advice, Stay away if you want to progress with your career.

review_title: DB tech center - a place where you can grow, but learn patience to deal with bureaucracy
job_title: Senior QA Manager in Bucharest, Bucuresti
pros:
- Great team spirit in the projects I worked in
- Helpful and nice colleagues of all ages  (medium age is around 30)
- In crisis situations (on the projects I am working on) management provides all support needed to unblock them 
- Support for learning and development
- A place where to further develop management and negotiation skills
cons:
- A fair share of bureaucracy - but it is expected for a bank of such calibre
- Old processes that are changing slowly (but at least people are trying to change them) - again to be expected for such a large bank
- Unclear delineation between internal and external employees - who should take ownership of what - although the overall company mission is to internalize IT skills for the time being
- Unclear IT repatriation strategy

review_title: Overall a good place to work
job_title: Kyc Specialist in New York, NY
pros: A large population of employees some of whom have a wealth of experience and have been with the bank for a long period as well as plenty of young and dynamic people with fresh ideas. Because it is an international bank that services clients in Europe and Latin America, its employees reflect that ethnic diversity. It is also pretty easy to make connections with others in different groups and departments, which makes learning about the bank and new opportunities much easier.
cons: My team was a fairly new one so there was a lack of existing infrastructure for its management and development. Because of that, the grounds were shifting and expectations fluctuated in ways that made it difficult to anticipate what was expected of us.

job_title: Assistant Vice President Software Engineer in Cary, NC
pros:
-- Good Place to play politics and Survive
-- Get here to learn how to survive without work by playing politics.
cons:
--Everything is in control of London. Cary is just an service based offshore location, People here on H1b are treated as Slaves. Node your head of what London Say. Otherwise get ready to be fired.
--There is a reason why Deutsche bank had Bad reputation in Market. Here is the Answer : People who works here
--Come here to get frustrated easily without knowing what you are coding and how is it useful to bank. Zero learning curve.
--Terrible People. People play lot of politics in own team to survive.
--No Clear requirements of what they want, but still you need to get product delivered or get ready to be blamed.
-- No one is interested to listen to Team concerns. Management feel offended if you do that.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Moscow, Moskva
pros:
- Good salary when you start working
- Good engineers - you can improve your tech skills here.
cons:
- The most stressful environment ever. You get the salary that is 20% and then work as 2 engineers. 
- You never hear "thank you" or "good job"
- 80% of engineers never increase their salary
- only 10-15% of engineers get the annual bonus - usually that means they are b*tches or genius
- performance review process kills your mood and motivation. The only thing you should do to make carrier in DB is so-called visibility - that means more meetings, more calls, more criticizing of you colleges - just don't spend your time for coding. That is useless. 
- no HR department - that means nobody cares about your satisfaction.
- no sport compensation, no trips, no cookies, no corporate events

review_title: Top quality work without the staggering burden of super-egos.
job_title: Assistant Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Tremendous opportunities for international postings and development of a global focus.  Ego tripping strongly dis-incentivized. The company is more proactive in evaluating employee strenghts/interests and seeking out opportunities for development and that perfect next assignment.
cons: Compensation structure and progression strangely rigid. The technology products can be somewhat outmoded, but are getting better. This may seem like a strange personal prejudice, but it's my contention that any organization that stubbornly refuses to move away from using Lotus Notes will never be the best at whatever it does -- we all have our litmus tests, I suppose.

review_title: Deutsche Bank - a good place to acquire skills for use at another company!
job_title: Associate- Asset Management in Chicago, IL
pros:
- tuition reimbursement
- tons of pto
- looks good on resume
- inexpensive health care 
- overall excellent benefits package
- a good place to gain experience for use at other companies
cons:
- miles of red tape 
- management does not trust employees - they literally have to know where you are and what you are doing at all times.  I witnessed managers looking through cracks in bathroom stalls to find a person.  They keep files with records of when employees come and go throughout the day.
- DB does not empower it's employees - they don't trust their people to get the job done without extreme micromanagement.  
- management seems incapable of making effective, timely,  decisions.  
- dated, 30 year old systems supported by inept IT support (tata consulting)
- Deutsche Bank was involved with the Nazi's 
- inconsistent review procedures and expectations 
- if you are not tight with your boss you will go nowhere - they will promote from outside.

review_title: Moscow Deutsche bank is generally good place to work for IT guy, though it depends on team where you work
job_title: Senior Java Developer in Moscow, Moskva
pros:
1) There is always possibility to move to another team / project if you wish so
2) You can find interesting work even in so not creative area as programming finance products
3) Salary in moscow is higher than in average moscow software company
4) You can be late on work in case you overall performance well
cons:
1) promotions/salary increase one time per year
2) if you get to not right team , you will need to work there for a year at least
3) a lot of boring work if you want to be promoted - so high skilled programmers cant be VP
even if they have a great experience they need to do paper work t be promoted (russian mentality that programmer cant be important person)

review_title: Don't work there if you want to be respected and have a life!
pros: Nothing at all.  Not a good place to work.
cons:
Worked 11 to 12 hours a day contracting doing 3 people's jobs quite a lot of the time as other two permanent colleagues were pretty much useless.  One came in late and left on time and the other who had been there so long bought holiday and was often on leave rather than at work.  They also took full and extended lunch breaks.  One of them took a fair amount of time off sick.

Office equipment antiquated and time consuming.  IT the worst, taking weeks to get back to you and then not resolving matters, basically hoping you would forget the problem or find a work around yourself.

Analysts and associates rude and pompous, petulant children basically.  And as with so many large organisations, Directors just stuck their head in the sand and did nothing.

Office filthy and had to regularly clean desk location personally.

review_title: Too much is on paper only rather than in the culture
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Frankfurt am Main
pros: Banks can be deeply impersonal places, and DB is no exception. It does try to customise the work experience more than some, but the rudderlessness apparent from the outside extends to all departments inside.
cons: Too much lip service to competence. Examples included thousands of posters for a "matched giving scheme" that turns out not to be significantly funded to match even the donation of a single employee, Hard-coded spreadsheets with errors that noone can correct, a time-wasteful / pointless box-ticking compliance process, a lack of interest in producing the best product, but a focus on image over substance.

review_title: Entrepreneurial ethos, some people can find it too fast moving. Long hours. Only get out what you put in.
pros: Competent employer. Fast moving.  Not everyones ideal employer as structures and information is not always clear. Need to be someone who makes an effort, finds things out and gets things done to be rewarded.
cons:
Tends to get run on a famine and feast basis in terms of investment.  Investment in staff, technology etc... tends to be very up and down, which some people can find fustrating to work with.
On the other hand this is indicative of the entrepreneurial culture.  Ups and downs inevitably mean that there are annual rounds of firing people.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: The people were great, but we were all stressed recently. Lots of options to move internally if you are proactive and work hard. Like any large organization, understanding how to get things done and knowing who is who is a major element of success. I had several great bosses and colleagues, we made it through many challenges as a team. I consider them great friends, period.
cons: The company itself is going through major changes still remaining from the 2007-2008 financial crisis. Some business units and departments will thrive, and others will shrink. Do you own homework to evaluate the opportunity for yourself.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Cary, NC
pros:
Some good people interested in the well being of the bank and its products. I think the bank is a good starting platform for anyone. It has a good reputation.
Good work life balance and reasonable mobility 
Benefits are just ok, not great. They offer a lot of benefits, but on the low end of the scale.
cons:
Lots of people interested in self promotion and stardom. Sabotaging your projects and going behind one's back is not uncommon. Some leads hide behind the phrase "team effort" or "team" to avoid giving well deserved individual credit. Most important decisions are made in London or NY, leaving only low level autonomy to Cary.
