No raises or bonuses in the two years I spent there.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Frankfurt am Main
pros: Various areas of the Bank you can work in.  Relatively easy to move laterally if you do well.  I worked with a lot of good people in various areas.  I would give the company a solid 3 stars here but the reason for the 2 stars is in the Cons.
cons:
Hard to be promoted.  You can be promoted in theory- i.e. start the job, be successful in the job, but formal promotions and raises take place only once a year.  So be careful.  If you get 
"promoted " in March, you will most likely not get the title or pay until perhaps February of the following year.  My advice is only take a promotion during the promoting month because at the end of the day you may never get the promotion or pay promised.  I saw this happen to several colleagues which I feel is totally unethical.

pros: John Cryan is a great CEO.  He has clarified the banks strategy internally and externally. Keeps it simple.  Very approachable and down to earth. A refreshing change from the previous regime. Seems to genuinely care about employees, diversity, retaining talent and doing the right thing.
cons: Management Board commitments about diversity, developing and retaining talent and career mobility are not delivered by middle and senior management.

job_title: Senior Technical Program Manager in Cary, NC
pros: The people try very hard to make it work.  The community groups are good to get people engaged.  Overall the people create a good environment.  I learned a lot there.   Cloud adoption is a focus, so get in on the ground floor there for learning about this.   Not a bad place to get your feet wet and start a career.  Agile methods are attempted, again a good place to get started.   Benefits are very good, and pay is above average.
cons:
The executive team is in London.  It is possible to  get noticed, but it is harder with them all being remote.  Promotions above a certain level are limited outside of the main location.  

Collaborative tooling is limited, making it a challenge to work with remote team members.

review_title: DB doing better than most of its peers at this point, but is that saying much?
pros: Deutsche Bank is an investment bank (as well as commercial in non-US regions) of rising global / local reputation and clout. As a result, employee quality will hopefully rise over time.
cons: Business units are independent, hardened silos with little cross pollination of ideas and/or services that could be exploited for greater corporate gain. This is due to the highly political and territorial nature of businesses whose management were headhunted from other top tier banks (or integrated via acquisition) and are therefore deeply distrustful of the motives of colleagues whom they perceive as political adversaries contesting for the same pot of gold.

review_title: Working as Product Controller in Manila Service Center
pros:
- good pay compared to other local companies
- nice office and facilities
- lots of available trainings
- can get to travel for "free"
cons:
- promotion is flawed. no clear cut qualifications how you'll be promoted. 
- have to be friends with senior bosses to be recognized otherwise you will get nowhere
- no definite career path. this is definitely just a job. growth means = complicatd products = more working hours 
- to many expats justifying their presence. too many "projects" they wanna do which of course means more admin work. 
- just one of of the resources
- politics
- miserable non-monetary benefits that you can take home and share with your family

review_title: A good bank with some compromise
job_title: Vice President Business Development in Milan
pros: They promote accountability and rely a lot on personal willingness. People passionate to the banking and financial environment can find here a very good place to enhance their performances and meet their goals.
cons: All the cons linked to a big/global bank: bureaucracy, inefficiencies, lack and waste of resources that, a different level, have an impact on your job and plans.

review_title: Good for lateral moves and travel. Not good for growth.
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Some good some bad managers. The young teams are most fun. Work hard play hard. Pay is not the best but still sufficient and usually bonus is 10-30% based on bonus.
cons: The HR process and politics are real. To get a raise it is not the manager's decision but the HR department. They do not know how much you are putting in and spread the wealth according to company needs not department needs. Lateral moves are easy and moving to a different location is usually do-able but moving up might come down to having someone leave before the position opens. Jobs are very siloed, so cross training is limited therefore limiting growth opportunities.

pros: This organization is dedicated to leveraging superior technical talent to build next-generation applications for the bank.  They are willing to take the time to make the right design decisions and take the longer view of building applications across silos to decrease long-term costs.
cons: Navigating the bureaucracy to get anything done, especially as it relates to even the simplest modifications to production systems is very painful.  Organizational politics and power grabs are a bit ruthless for my taste.

pros: I haven't been in company for single day as HR didn't completed his formalities from his side.
cons:
Will tell you whole story and then you find out the cons. I got selected and got sufficient hike. HR forced me to resign and buy out the notice period as the requirement was at earliest. So I did the same as HR told me. Now, Before 2 days of joining date I asked him what documents need to carried at the time of joining, on which he said we need more documents without which your joining can not happen. 
Here there was no HR initiative as it was his work where as on top of that he was asking me the document at the time of joining. And without document your joining wont happen. I was shocked and surprised. I asked them why you didn't intimated it before. 
Don't trust HR of this company.

job_title: Investment Banking Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: It can be a means to an end, but not to the level of other bulge bracket investment banking platforms
cons:
The franchise is completely unstable, and has degraded over the last few years.  You will not even get a meaningful investment banking experience due to senior turnover in the last few years in core verticals (Healthcare / TMT), ongoing litigation concerns, and an inability to compete or attract talent.  Your seat is absolutely not guaranteed.

You WILL be expected to work investment banking hours with an investment banking attitude.  You will work for unambitious, incompetent managers that have no genuine care for your development (or sanity).  The stock's not undervalued; it's just actually that crappy of a platform.  I wish you the best of luck if you commit to DB, because you will certainly need it.    

Cons (bulleted):
- Bureaucracy and face time
- Horrible hours that are detrimental to mental and physical health
- Incompetence and lack of leadership at mid level (Associate & VP) 
- No meaningful deal flow or professional development
- Massive turnover and layoffs at all levels (incl. junior levels)

review_title: No thinking, just give me a result!
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Moscow, Moskva
pros: Well paid in my location. Nice office.
cons:
Huge bureaucracy and partially non-working processes. You need to have strong informal relationships to setup back-doors for delivering things in a timely fashion. Teams contain engineers with extremely different level of skills, but tasks are allocated randomly not in alignment with the skills. Not enough QAs. Thanks to this environment, a code quality could be much better. Fast delivery instead of elaborate design is everywhere.

"Agile methodologies" on a paper, chaotic development in reality. As a result, the work is looking more and more as fighting with fire.

review_title: DB Risk Centre oversold and underpaid
pros: Berlin is a lively alternative city. Work life balance is quite good
cons:
DB Risk Centre is sold as a unique division of DB with great talents. However the level of workers is very uneven and it is not uncommon to see managers with no experience at all either managing or in banking. Turnover is incredibly high, around 1 year, which means: you go, realise it is not for you within one month and start looking somewhere else.
Many people from Italy, Spain, Greece think they are offered a good salary compared to their countries, but the truth is that it is dramatically below the average for Germany. There were legal actions against DB Risk Centre for contracting people with salaries below legal minima.
It is a compromise between Frankfurt and Mumbai: donkey work slightly cheaper than in the headquarter.

review_title: DB struggles to get it right
pros: DB hires intelligent, sharp people and provides a good landscape to learn and develop.  There is alot going on in the bank and jumping into any one of the massive problems (because there are many!) will certainly provide you with alot of learning opportunities.
cons:
Driven by a desperate need to slash their costs and improve the abysmal cost-income ratio DB has taken to scaling back on compensation, and inculcated an extremely stringent cost control agenda which creates excessive red-tape and bureaucracy.  
All in all, the bank has not done a great job in transforming the culture into a more leaner, more agile & more proactive culture.  The bank still largely works in silo's.

pros:
Annual Leave - PTO and Vacation Allotment
Benefits (Health Insurance and 401k)
Ability to work from home 
Location - Southside
cons:
Promotion, Compensation Policy (Merit Raise, Bonus)
Data Quality and IT issues
Mismanagement - lack of concern for employees
Corporate Culture Not Defined

review_title: No longer the place for ambitious juniors
job_title: Assistant Vice President, Finance in London, England
pros: Opportunities for juniors to take on a lot of responsibility quickly. Colleagues are intelligent and hard working.
cons: Divisional mergers have resulted in overcrowding of Directors/VPs in several teams, actually taking work away from juniors in some cases. Unnecessary management layers, increasing barriers to promotion, and zero performance-related bonus for employees below VP level make DB a wasted venture for any Finance Analyst-AVP with ambition. A lot of stress and responsibility for zero rewards. Morale is low across the bank.

pros:
Respectful co-workers. 
Workload and therefore working hours are generally less than peer banks’.
cons:
Bureaucracy is massively excessive in this organisation and this is used as a substitute for strategic and adaptive thinking. This is also leveraged by individual Execs to hide behind and avoid having to ‘pin their colours to any particular mast’. 
Governance = Project Tracking (only).
A remarkable proportion of permanent workforce are MDs i.e. Lifers who have achieved seniority through length of tenure rather than competence or talent. 
Long-term financial woes have led to a ‘long-stemmed poppy syndrome’ where higher-paid staff are being released solely based on remuneration level diluting what little talent is left further. 
Control of the organisation now seems to reside with Finance who have little grasp of what goes on in the respective departments.

pros:
This is place where technology meets and finance. We build vast majority of technology to the bank including connectivity, pricing, risk, data warehousing. On a business there is fx, fixed income, money markets, options - so all verity of financial instruments are for you. If you enjoy finance and (server side) technology it would be the best place to work in St. Petersburg.
Company provides good opportunities for trainings including all soft of soft skills, technology skills and participating in relevant meetings.
For graduates there is amazing Java School which not only teaches with advanced (and demanded in real world) tricks in Java but also provides jobs with amazing compensations.
cons:
Getting promoted to managerial positions might be tricky in some teams (however is relatively easy in others)
Big distance to the actual business built by organisation

pros: I think one of the best (and potentially worse) reasons to work with Deutsch Bank is the conservative business model that seems to have assured we didn't get whacked like so many of our peers during the economic downturn.  The other pluses are salaries, global environment and generally nice people
cons: We are about 10 years behind other tech organizations on the street.  Folks get beaten down by the fear of change into apathy.  Policies and culture are too stringent - no room for creativity or an entrepreneurial mindset.  It's not a fun place to work either as there is no sense of unified vision or camaraderie.

pros: Mostly nice, smart people.  great on-site cafeteria. great perks include free admission to a lot of NYC museums and galleries through DB sponsorship of culture.
cons: i'm guessing that it's all about cost savings; IT support is very spotty.  from time to time you get someone who actually knows what they're doing.  most of the time one gets the impression of a person reading from a script who may not be able to find the on/off switch without instructions; nice people, but totally not up to the job.  makes for frustration when a (sometimes) minor tech issue takes weeks to resolve.

review_title: Time to move over and make way for the next generation Jo!
pros: Great opportunities, job constantly changing and easy to get more responsibility if you have a good performance history and are eager to take on more.  The organisation is happy to move people around according to business need and personal priorities.  Not a great inter-company mobility process but if you have a good network and can navigate the organisation then international and cross-divisional movesa are pretty easy
cons: The hours and mediocre compensation (I've been there a while so have lagged compared to the market)

review_title: could be an awesome place if they want it to be
pros: this was a great place to work with a great deal of product. They have a great entrepreneurial spirit there and allow a great degree of freedom for what product you wish to sell. One of the most complete platforms to work on in the Private Client wealth business. Great product people to help with your clients. Internal competition is at a minimum. Lots of green initiatives
cons: The division is not high on the firms pecking order. No formal training. need to find things out for yourself. high degree of favoritism.

review_title: Going the right direction in NC
pros:
Base salary, benefits, and 401k are top tier in the local market. Great location on Weston, solid cafe and gym on site, near greenway that connects with lots of trails. Bonus calculation was overhauled this year, last years was decent even in a rough patch for the bank. 

Software dev tooling greatly improving YoY, catching up (but not there yet) with modern practices. Moving faster than most SIFIs I would imagine.

Lots of thorny problems to solve with code, and the average caliber around you is quite high. Site represents many business lines and infrastructure functions.
cons: Paperwork during onboarding and paperwork getting a project started. Paperwork at deployment time. Paperwork getting your machine configured.

review_title: An incredible oppoportunity that turned out to be my worst career move with my worst boss/employer in 15 years.
pros: DB paid for the best talent and it has it.  They are the banks greatest asset.
cons: The bank is unable to differiniate talent, assets and egos.  It's struggling with globalization and heavy with bureacracy.  Additionally, when senior management is frequently seeking out the advice of HR it is a sign that there is something terribly wrong with a company.

pros: Prestigious name to have on cv.
cons:
From an IT perspective, 5+ years ago Deutsche was a great bank hiring the best people. Most of the good people have since left, leaving behind the dead wood. Why?
- no longer pays top money
- bureaucratic organisation makes it hard to get things done
- creativity and innovation are stifled
- jumps on the nearest bandwagon but is always behind the curve, never leading
- too focused on cost cutting, and often in the wrong places
- too many layers of ineffective management
- decision makers sit in ivory towers and do not engage with the troops until after decisions have been made
- cronyism
- lack of 360 reviews resulting in poor quality management team
- replacing good quality, experienced on-shore staff with cheaper off-shore staff
- poor quality IT systems

pros:
- you get 18 weeks of paid maternity leave if you have a child
- If you happen to get on the right team, this is not a bad place to work.
- Great medical insurance
cons:
- 1 week of paternity leave
- good teams are few and far between
- Exceptional workers are few and far between
- medical insurance is pricy
- Company is stingy with perks.  For instance, Christmas celebrations and what not came out of our own pockets, no paid first day lunch, etc.
- Developers have a lot of red tape to deal with that makes development more difficult
- Full time developers are treated as if they are another contracting agency by the business
- not enough bathrooms :)

review_title: Creates second class employees through outsourcing
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Reasonable salary/benefits and work/life balance.  Gives lip service to fostering a diverse work culture. Reasonably smart employees overall.
cons: Took advantage of market conditions and outsourced a group of long-term research employees that they needed but not longer respected to a firm with no experience in the business line, thereby creating a second-class set of de facto DB employees (as employees remained in their same desks/offices, performing the same jobs, but no longer eligible for the same benefits). Anyone who didn't accept the offer from the third rate outsourcing firm was denied severance and terminated.  Outsourcing firm has no idea how to run the business line -- completely dependent on the transferred employees to make the transaction work.

review_title: No performance driven,  despite slogans. Very good only in words and in formal way, but beside that, mediocrity.
pros: Colleagues are ok. Premises are very good. Canteen food was a bit better before but still good and quite affordable.
cons: Management at first appears competent, then you realize it is all smoke and appearance. Bonuses not paid because of US trading fines

job_title: Assistant Vice President in New York, NY
pros: This place was is a good starter for your career, because you learn to do everything, since that is the only way work gets completed.  Good vacation time and benefits.
cons: The management here is the worst.  I've had good managers in the beginning, but as time went by there was a strong lack of knowledge from the management.  Careless decision making, which puts the bank at great risk.

pros: Good transport facility, every hour there is cab facility. Can expect good hike and bonus if your manager are good with you. Good brand value. Can enroll for class room trainings to enhance your skill.
cons: Most of manager you will find here working from banking domain only.  So they expect to work as they see in his previous organization, in other word they are spoiling healthy work culture of DB. They use to hire/refer their previous employers colleague irrespective of deserving or not and they will give preference to them as compare to other employees. So running project unfair way.  Highly egoistic managers. They feel like they are only owner of company as they can do what they want. You are lucky if you get a good professional manager. All the best for you guys.

review_title: Very positive learning experience during which I was treated exceptionally well
job_title: Intern in City of London, England
pros:
Business: Strong European bank, more business thanks to balance sheet use.
Culture: Very open culture. People willing to help all the time. Was shown around by different people in the bank from many different teams. From analyst to senior management always found some time to talk to you, take you out for a lunch and chat, answer questions.
Social: Events were organised to meet other interns and also business representatives. Well organised and fun. Information provided before hand to allow to prepare.
Extra: HR is very helpful and well organised. Flexibility with important issues, tries to accommodate different needs. Catering is wonderful compared to other places, as is location, in a large building in the City of London.
cons: Possibly a smaller, younger investment bank. Less brand name in the investment banking industry, although it is one of the largest and well-known universal banks.

review_title: Good culture, let down somewhat by 'revolving door' middle management and disruptive re-orgs
pros:
Salaries are broadly in line with industry peers
Good culture with respect to social events; corporate social responsibility
Work life balance often viewed better than US peers
Senior management strategy is clear and good however sometimes diluted by middle management political agendas
cons:
Stack ranking rating system is often applied at too small a sample set and can be catastrophic for morale and increases turnover of high performers
It is an organisation where often perception and visibility can be more important for career growth than delivery
Senior management mistrust of middle management can result in an overly bureaucratic culture where even tiny things require an excess of management level approval

pros:
1. Flexible work timings.
2. Cab facility.
3. Good exposure in terms of work.
4.  Fair ratings in terms of appraisals.
5.  Decent Salaries.
6. Good place for ladies to have work - life balanced life.
cons:
1. No Work from Home facility.
2. Lot of Politics in few teams.
3. Work allocation not uniform accross the team (few people have no work, while other have to time for lunch).

review_title: An education in having to seek talent internally through politics, passengers and plodders to get things done
pros: As long as you deliver above average you get away with a lot  which allows a fairer work life balance. Working with a few very clever people who can be extremely good to work with.
cons: Full of long term employees who rely on internal contacts to massage themselves into right position. Some very clever people struggle to deliver against the tide of politics and passengers that only do what they have to do to keep their boss happy rather than help the general company try to improve in a more matrix way

review_title: DB won't invest in its Private Wealth Management Americas business
pros: Entrepreneurial environment allows success but with limitations. If you can bring in wealthy, low-risk clients, this is an okay place for you depending on the branch manager. If you are support staff you may have the opportunity to share commissions but it depends on the brokers you work with who can be generous, stingy, or somewhere in between.
cons: If you are support staff, there is no room for professional growth.  DB will not approve tuition reimbursement. You will not be promoted. DB Private Wealth Management has entrenched operations processes that are inefficient. DB PWM Americas is overly cautious so finding new business can be a challenge at times. Support software for account performance monitoring, trading, or opening new accounts is outdated and slow.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Some departments offer cutting edge technology related work, some are very client centric. Mostly operational roles in Jacksonville. Work-Life balance is great! A lot of work from home opportunities and mobility program is really good.
cons: Too bureaucratic, a lot of layers in everything which slows down the time to deliver. The only vision which is clear is cost cutting. Promotion / Incentives are non-existant. Appraisal process is too subjective resulting in different reasons each time for not promoting or rating one. A lot of focus on values and beliefs but only at AVP or below layer, at the top there seems to be almost reverse.

job_title: File Clerk in Santa Ana, CA
pros: Full-time hours and OT.  The break room has all you can drink coffee and tea free of charge but the cushions are all torn up and it's usually a mess.
cons: The bank uses mostly agency staff - Advantage Resources in Costa Mesa. Their staff is great.  However, no benefits, no vacation time, you miss a day and are put on the s list.  The VP over the vault is a dragon! Pounds on bathroom stall if you are in there too long. in the vault, only the VP and senior supervisor are permanent DB staff. The hundred other staff are at-will agency staff.

review_title: Staff Augmentation!  Come here to be bored.
job_title: Software Development Engineer in Cary, NC
pros: There's a free fitness center.  There's a cafe.  You get lots of vacation.  In some teams, you can do absolutely nothing, work 5 hours a day and go home.   If you are a mediocre developer, if you can get onto a team on the second floor, you might have a long career there.  Bonuses used to be good.  Salaries are good.  Insurance is good.  If you can put up with it working here, you'll have a good chance to be poached by a different company.
cons:
The office in Cary is filled with incompetent senior managers.  The least competent is at the top, followed by the management team.  Why?  Because they're cast-offs, or imports from elsewhere.  The ones in banking don't understand software development, and the ones in software are the people fired from middle management of other companies.  

This is honestly a dead-end if you want a career.  They talk about "expert path" for technical people which doesn't exist, at least not in Cary.  You will have no autonomy as all the decisions are made in London and NY.  Your senior manager is put in place by those same teams nervous about hiring outside of the hubs, so his job is just to work you until you quit and not to make any noise such as picking good software or practices.  Your failure provides them cover to not transfer jobs from their location.  They have never promoted anyone in Cary to a senior position- the last three directors weren't even from other Deutsche Bank locations; they went outside the company instead of promote one of the more than 100 existing managers or senior developers.  There is a serious flight of talent- other companies are easily able to poach people who are competent, able to work under pressure, and worth every penny of their salary.  Speaking of which, you used to get a bonus for all the downsides mentioned above.  No more.   It depends on the performance of the company  to get a maximum of 4%.  Take a look at the stock and you'll see how unlikely that is.    Diversity is overdone- protected groups can't be fired, and no one cares to take the time to hire good talent, they just want to have bodies to fill their hiring quotas.  The center head stood up in front of the employees at a town hall and said he's going to hire 50% women. What happened to equal opportunity hiring?   Oh and the fitness center and cafe mentioned as "pro" are just 'meh', but I had to say something nice to fill in that box.  Which is what you'll do for several hours a week- mandatory training classes for financial stuff which you'll never use as a developer but bureaucracy rules.  The HR team is horrible- they live in a little private area, through a card-key door, so you can't interact with them.  If you ask them a question, they'll reply with "call the hotline'.  Everyone desk is a 'trading desk', meaning they've crammed people into huge open areas with the same double-monitor and phone on the side of the desks with employees 5-wide and back to back.  Even call centers have more room.  They've got 800+ people in one building that other residents of the office park have closer to 300 in theirs.  If you need time to concentrate on working out a difficult debugging or clever software solution: give up.  The noise level doesn't allow it (*See working late or weekends comment).  This sardine-like setup also has an unfortunate characteristic of if someone skips a shower, everyone knows it.

review_title: long hours little pay while the big cats are just getting bigger
pros: the best reason to work here are the direct people that i with.  the staff members are a very hard working group.  i wish i could say the same for managment.  We do have a good location and a good cafe.  vacation is ok but i do not like the fact that i must take 7 working day off in a row just to met a MTA requirment.
cons: i work a lot of long hours.  i do not have a life outside of this building.  each year there is a big turn over at bonus time.  i have seen very big bonsues but not for the line workers.

review_title: Jaipur has no independent identity or standing in any business decisions or work environment.
pros:
Nice work environment
Work place is appealing clean and well maintained with good premises and work conditions.
Transport has improved a lot with timely pick up and drops
Work life balance is maintained
Nice incentives for learning
cons:
Jaipur does not have its independent identity
All decisions are driven by Managers siting in Mumbai/Bangalore
No support from AVPs or VPs. They are just technical heads with no involvement in driving change or improving people involvement
Worst is Managers are more postmen instead of heads who can drive change
Work is totally with lower level management and higher levels only delegate their work and responsibility while claiming success for others work.
HR is afraid to take action or verify any mis-work or complaint and it is just informed to management as an improvement point

pros: Excellent pay and benefits.  Local center has a lot of fun activities (provided you have enough time in your schedule to participate) and supports diversity.
cons: I walked into a mess.  Senior leadership seems support unproductive and unprofessional behavior among the D ranks which is felt downwards throughout the organization.  This has been a career low.  I am thoroughly disappointed in the lack of maturity and unproductive atmosphere.  Shakeup in the senior ranks leave them scrambling to find sacrificial lambs.  This is not a direct reflection of the local leadership, but rather leadership in reporting lines sitting in other offices.

review_title: Great place to work, but not without caveats.
pros: Very thin personal ranks allows for rapid advancement and assumption of increasing responsibility by young employees. Very intelligent people who have managed to avoid the majority of the pitfalls of the current credit crisis, by being on the right side of the ABS market and instead generating revenue from foreign exchange and rates departments.  Stable banking (retail banking) platform also enables the bank to avoid funding issues and runs on money. Slightly lower returns on equity is acceptable if it enables the bank to be around in a year or two from now.
cons: European bank with headquarters in London puts less focus/understanding on US activities than US based investment banks.

pros: Benefits used to be great, now they are starting to cut those. Vacation time is good. Diversity policies are good, but too bad HR doesn't follow them.
cons: Where do I begin? This company has ruined the lives of so many people. I don't even want to waste my time listing all of the terrible things about this company. #1 thing to know: You are expendable. They have no problem losing anyone. In fact, their business model is to treat people bad so they quit so they can hire someone straight out of college and pay them 28k a year. Once you make "too much" money, kiss your job good by.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Cary, NC
pros:
If you're on the right team, everything is great. Mobility opportunities, advancement opportunities are plentiful as well - on the right team. Very easy to network with colleagues in other locations to build a personal network that is global. For a strong willed person, it is very easy to flourish.

On the right team, work life balance is perfect. You could not ask for better.

Compensation is great as well for the market, although it will need to be adjusted upwards over the next few years to account for new competitors.

Smart, talented people are the norm.

Very strongly defined set of company values.
cons:
Customer-centricity is the new push as a corporate value, but is little more than lip service on the ground. No KPIs have trickled down from the ExCo as to how this should be measured.

The organization as a whole is too top heavy. Constant emails from different ExCos about people we have no interaction with changing job roles and taking over responsibilities that aren't even obliquely related. This happens almost monthly, to no real benefit.

Constant re-orgs allow incompetent employees to hide and maintain their status. Little to no accountability for teams that manage vendors - the vendors always fail to deliver, and the teams managing them get away with it because of the constant re-orgs.

Tech projects are almost always top heavy. Too many people with no idea about what it takes to build a product involved in the process giving invalid opinions, trying to be the smartest person in the room. Too many meetings, too much design by committee. Projects run over budget and under deliver as a result. Business partners aren't held accountable for the failure and move on to new projects to continue the cycle of ruination.

Obstructionism by teams in other locations doing similar work is common. Land grabs for projects and people occur constantly with the re-orgs, allowing empires to be built. Middle management seems to solely be concerned with owning projects instead of delivering value.

review_title: best place for the politically connected
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in London, England
pros: DB is based in London Wall, so that is a better location for some, than canary wharf. You may do well in DB if you are a politician.
cons: Bonus system is not merit based, rather based on who you know. When I was there, I travelled to Frankfurt and did not get reimbursed travel expenses (flights, hotel) which proved expensive for me. When you want to move up, you have to move on, unless you are in with the right crowd. All in all, a rather unfriendly, officious and political place where you have to watch your back at all times.  I was in IT, maybe it's ok if you are a trader.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Looks good on your resume.
cons:
Worst culture - very hierarchical, even if seniors know a lot less than the juniors, they will make sure to make the junior staff feel inferior and worthless. Unless you serve as a slave to the senior that works from home almost everyday while you work away 60+ hours a week doing admin work, you're not going to get anywhere.

Overall, the bank is stuck 50 years behind. This is not a place for innovation, the recruitment team does a job making it look like a place of desire but do not be fooled. The infrastructure and technology is extremely outdated. The mindset of most senior staff is stuck in the 1950s. They make every effort to ensure not to promote women or minorities.

review_title: Best at providing work life balance
pros: One will get enormous time to settle with the organisation. If you are somebody who is tired of working under pressurized environment and now wanna do a easy out job opt for DB. Employees are given wide opportunities to focus on their hobbies and build their skills. For Ladies this is the best place to work.
cons:
Politics do exists unlike other organisations.
L&D is not up to the mark.
Try and excel by yourself.
If you are a career oriented person this place is not for you, Professionalism is not to the mark. 
Work is not categorized basis hierarchy.

review_title: Great work environment, management needs to pay attention to employees talents
pros: 401k (matching plan), nice vacation/personal days package, several in-house clubs and internal events, in-company gym (free membership), in-company nurse, great health/vision/dental options, standing desks, open office/open door environment, career mobility (domestic/overseas).
cons:
No carry-over of vacation days. Highly skilled professionals not recognized.

Operational inefficiencies, HR Policy (mobility/promotions) is not flexible which results talented people to leave the company/department in search of better opportunities, management not mature enough to foster talent development, talented professionals have.

job_title: Assistant Vice President Applications Developer in Cary, NC
pros: Friendly coworkers who care and put up with an awful lot while only occasionally exploding in frustration.
cons:
European management is hyper political and seemingly duplicitous.
New York culture disregards proper software engineering.
Lots of red tape.
Difficult to navigate.
Politics and turf wars.
Tactical noise.
All true design and authority is in NY and London, but they will try to hide this when you are first hired.
(I've worked elsewhere and the politics and deceit at DB was the worst)

review_title: A long and fulfilling career with the bank
pros:
- You get to work with great people from around the world
- Given the opportunity to work on challenging projects
- Mobility opportunities available to work around the globe
- Great CSR program for those that want to give back to the community
- Change is the only constant - a highly dynamic work environment
- Currently going through significant changes in the global strategy - this presents many opportunities if you are willing to stick your neck out
cons:
- Too much red tape and internal politics
- Change is the only constant... it's not a place for you to maintain the status quo
- Currently going through significant changes in the global strategy - some people may not like what is being changed

pros: Obtained a lot of good knowledge. Great exposure to markets, products, and large corporate firms. I also made a lot of great life long contacts.
cons: Great if you're in the front office, terrible for the rest of the firm. Technology was terrible. Everything outsourced. The employees in India had no idea what they were doing and we spent half the time cleaning up messes they created with big clients due to communication problems,etc. I worked 60 + hours a week. I was promoted and took a pay cut to $53,000 annually since I was no longer eligible for overtime. I asked for a $2,000 raise and was told no, but they'd give me a corporate phone (which made no sense). Left the firm shortly thereafter.

pros:
(1) Fantastic office / facilities / location.
(2) Huge variety of societies and social events run by employees.
(3) Diverse workforce.
cons:
(1) Very few talented Managers / Team Leaders.
(2) Lack of defined career paths / direction.
(3) Painfully slow career progression for junior employees (approx 4 years from Intern to Associate).
(4) Career mobility is not promoted.
(5) Loyalty is not rewarded.
(6) Silo'd mentalities, globally and locally.
(7) Forget 'Passion to perform' the DB tag-line should be; 'it's not what you know, but who you know'.

review_title: One of the best employers in Romania
pros:
This is a relatively new company and you should consider this in the first place. Being a new company there might be ups and downs, but also because of this reason, the opportunities are great.
Pros start from the top (Romanian) management who is always busy to build and keep a work environment at the highest standards.  The company has its offices in one of the most reliable anti-seismic (in my opinion) buildings of Bucharest. Colleagues were great; salary is very good, but negotiable.
cons: Sometimes things might get unclear with DB Group, like in any corporation, and that could affect some people or some departments. At the same time the Romanian management and HR are taking seriously these situations, to ensure the place and satisfaction of each employee.

review_title: Wait until DB is out of their net loss
job_title: Associate Software Engineer Developer in Cary, NC
pros: People at the Cary location and pretty cool and easy to talk to.
cons: They laid off all the considerate managers who realize that you are an adult and treat you as such. Don't expect any kind of raise at all for at least 2 years as they pretty much only give raises with promotions and the most often you get that is every 2 years and even then, it won't be very competitive.

review_title: Management needs to be more aware in order to perform at a top level
pros: Very competitive Benefits and Vacation time.  People are generally nice and easy to get along with.  Generally people are helpful on the projects.  Technology Systems are coming up to speed with the new technologies, but have a ways before getting there.
cons: Management Not Trustworthy, Promotions are very limited in CA, Mortgage business is struggling.  Management outside of Santa Ana is not aware of what is happening elsewhere.  Many times management outside of Santa Ana would make decisions without knowledge of people or situations, causing morale problems.  Working with Outsource clients was difficult as management forced situations on employees, even when it wasn't the best solutions.  Clearly looking only at price and not quality of product.

pros: decent benefits and average hours.  you can learn a lot if you work for the right group or person.  company has internal e-learning classes that everyone can enroll and learn at his own pace.  it also has a very strong relationship with colleges/universities where it recruits summer interns from both the undergrad and grad programs.  most interns are offered a full time position.
cons: a lot of politics and people not willing to share information.  difficult to get a promotion unless you make sure to strategize visibility to upper management. it used to sponsor for MBA but it's since been cut this year due to trimming on cost.  company still sponsors for certificate and other short programs and conferences.  managers sometimes take credit for your work and they don't do much themselves.

review_title: bad to worse for finance folks
job_title: Assistant Vice President Finance in Hong Kong
pros: excellent bank to learn all the funky, high end wall street structure finance products and latest derivatives innovations......smart people around you, performance driven, nice office at ICC
cons: unfortunately the DB systems have not catch up with their innovative products and also huge outsourcing move to Mumbai and Manila have curtailed any improvement for finance and ops...not a long term career place. High turnover problems in these outsourcing hubs did not improve the overall production process and working hours....onshore guys left to work harder to fix these issues and get charged back even more expensive for these hub services....where is the logic??

pros: Working there for the last 4 years. Good exposure to a large International Bank, people are friendly and open. But do not look for more than that.
cons:
There are 3 fundamental issues with Deutsche. Pay is low, well below average. Promotion is slow and non transparent. Finaly the management contiuously annonce new strategy. A lot of stamina is lost in this process because pleople discuss more about the coming reorg than they do work... Everyone speaks about these 3 issues, hence motivation is very low.
2 additional issues : most  IT deliveries are failures. Management seems to have no clue about how to build a good investment bank.

review_title: Nice and relaxed place to work with minimal technical growth
pros: It's a fair and ethical company they care about the employee. Work- life balance is wonderful. The team size for most of the teams is perfect, they just don't hire people for the sake of it. Infrastructure and facilities are awesome. Most importantly, everyone right from top of hierarchy is on time for every meeting.
cons: The technical growth is totally dependent on your project you are assigned to, once you are tagged to the project that is about maintaining the developed project. Most of your time would be to understand the domain and not the new techs. They focus more on stability rather performance.

review_title: Deutsche Bank provided good benefits, mixed review of managers and policies
job_title: Corporate Loans in New York, NY
pros: The company is large and well-respected.  They offer great benefits, very generous maternity leave. I felt very well taken-care-of by the company.  I never saw any discrimination or unfair treatment of employees.  Everyone behaved professionally, in my experience.
cons: I really don't have any problem with the company itself.  The only problems I had were the usual complaints about co-workers and a few managers I'd had over the years.  The manager I had when I left the company was terrific, so I can't really complain.

review_title: Organisation heavy with Vendors .Do not encourage and promote Technology Professionals
pros: Office Culture is OK .Nothing too exciting . This organisation in India is run by Operations Head with least or minimum participation from IT Leaders
cons: Development Centre for Promotion is eye washer . Mostly people from Operations and IGT get promoted . Global CIO is preaching to be technology focussed but fact is in the current restructuring IGT and Operations Leaders assigned responsibilities to run Technology organisation as CIO's

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Great place to learn about banking, the people who work there are definitely the reason why I have been with this company for 15 years. Also a good employer to request foreign assignments, especially in Asia.
cons: Important decisions are not taken nearly quick enough, or not at all. Processes and systems are tedious and not user-friendly, not synched centrally which leads to a lot of frustration and manual repetitive admin tasks. The glass ceiling between VPs and Directors is huge, people at the top have no idea what is going down on the ground.

review_title: A great exercise in what NOT to do.
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
Pay
Benefits
Perks
Hours
Cafeteria
401k match 
I can’t think of anything else.
cons:
Upper management has no idea as to what their MDs are doing, and don’t care when you bring it to their attention.
Pass the buck and blame others culture.
Parent company in Germany does not care about regulatory implications and how it affects the US.
When you bring an idea to management for improvement, it’s shut down.

pros: i think db is generally a good place to work because the people are nice, good environment and generally a lot of opportunities for growth. Because db is a global company the opportunities for travel is enormous. Many of my colleagues have traveled to Moscow, London, Frankfurt, Sydney and Tokyo. I think compared to its pairs db is truly a global company. The internal training is good as well. There are a lot of classes available to develop your personal brand etc. DB is growing int he US and I think it creates many opportunities to be apart of something big.
cons: Sometimes in large organizations like this it can be way too bureaucratic. I think there is too much levels and roles, that creates and overly complex environment.

pros: The organization follows the European attitudes towards work life balance. Time off and flexible work schedules are usually not a problem. Most of the people are great to deal with.
cons:
Compensation is below market rate (at least in IT). Additionally, they are aggressively looking to outsource/off shore any thing they possible can. This leads to very poor moral and a feeling of just trying to get by day-to-day. 

For IT, the center of the universe is London, then Frankfurt, and finally NY. Get use to it.

job_title: Manager- Midlevel (Associate to Assistant Vice President) in Jacksonville, FL
pros: New CEO hopefully can turn things around.
cons: Poor management structure. Upper management is not close to the ground. Review process is obsolete and can be bias at times. Matrix management set-up is inefficient, upper management is more concerned about the bottom line than people (e.g. push back on a 1K increase for new hire). Many promises to deliver change but limited to no tangible results. Senior managers lack people development skills and are largely SME's promoted to positions based upon task knowledge and not key leadership attributes. During the review process, managers miss the big picture and tend to focus on 1-2 small mistakes instead of the year at hand all while overlooking their lack of leadership and involvement.

pros:
-Brand recognition (especially in Europe and Asia, not so much in the US recently because of the recent negative headlines)
-People are pretty nice compared to other IB's in SF; not as many egos
-Location (beats working in the South Bay)
-Very strong semiconductor practice (other verticals, not so much)
cons:
Aside from the typical cons of working in IB as a junior banker (such as long, unpredictable hours):
-Deal flow was lacking; possibly due to a lot of negative headlines in 2016-2017
-Infrastructure/technology is laughable. No such thing as collaborative software (i.e. Google docs)

pros:
Great office to work with, team members very supportive - particularly when asking or querying work that they have published (all renowned economists) 
Good hours, HR were very helpful - albeit to an intern
Work was very interesting; aided by the fact those above were very encouraging and willing to giving a helping hand when confused
cons:
Poor training - many company specific techniques were expected prior to joining
Seemed as though there was a poor promotion structure
Work sometimes seemed very menial with little difficulty or challenge

review_title: Good place to work but a lot of improvements are needed
pros: Large organization which equally large resources at a Global level. Overall package is very attractive with most of the people in a good competitive spirit
cons: Large organization with slow decision making and too many layers of management and too many decision makers. Simple decisions can take ages. That cost both time and money and more importantly frustration as progress in key areas is sometimes slow. The large grown of the bank over the last number of years was not followed by a similar drive to and streamline and have a global management structure with an easier decision matrix

job_title: Assistant Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
Smart and ambitious people. Unfortunately it's either or...
Great Training for soft skills , finance and technology. Top notch graduate program.
Excellent benefits. Competitive salaries. Above avarage vacation days.
cons: Unreasonably long hours. The place is a Sweatshop.

review_title: Deutsche Bank is a very good company to work for.
pros: Deutsche bank has very flexible working schedules for working Moms including on-sight day care in time of emergency. Great benefits including healthcare, matching 401K, pension benefits, 4 week minimum vacation.
cons: Frequent policy changes and restructuring and at times you'll be working towards a goal that is no longer a priority. We were told the bank is committed to a 25% ROI (Return on Equity) year over year which makes cost cutting a number one priority,  but recently found out that the goal was considered unrealistic and we should focus on providing quality. Slow steady growth with quality is now the main goal.

pros:
The best reasons for working at DB are a good rewards package, good team culture, and good senior management. For analysts the training is uncomparable eg. Modelling training, Graduate training in London for six weeks and regular M&A workshops detailing important issues in the industry.

Team culture is very strong with an informal, open-plan atmosphere with constant banter amongst analysts and associates and good connectivity with senior management.  As teams are small, get good involvement in major transactions and closeness with remaining team members. Everone is approachable including MDs, COO and Head of the Bank. We also have quarterly lunches with the Head of Banking to improve feedback to management.
cons: Downsides of working at DB include small teams, analyst under-hiring, and certain strong personalities

pros:
- Advancement is based on meritocracy.
- Benefits are among the best of it's competitors.
- Compensation is based on performance. High performers are paid well. Low performers are not.
cons:
- The internal HR recruiting is not great which makes moving between different groups at DB dependent on individuals but this has improved over the past couple of years
- Promotions can be very political as committees comprised of senior managers outside of evaluatee's organization are part of the process

review_title: Sold propoganda during the interview process
pros:
Great benefits
Great vacation policy
Big, global company with plenty exposure to colleagues in other countries
Noticeable efforts and perks to employees
cons:
IT Organization is one step below the state of chaos (CMM Level -1)
Many IT managers that are unqualified with little to no IT background
Lack of enterprise wide cognizance-so siloed that it has become a large issue
Weak mid-level management, although executive management is strong
Too many fiefdoms hindering the much needed cross collaboration in providing the right IT solutions
IT Value add - so much money spent on IT with so little to show for it.

review_title: AVP, Very excellent company as an employer, they offer great benefits
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Jersey City, NJ
pros:
My years at Deutsche Bank were very rewarding.
There is a balance of life/work experiences for working mothers.  I was a single working mother with 3 children and the manager assisted me by giving me flexible working hours.  This allowed me to work while my children were in school and I was with them when needed.
Salary was good
The great managers were very conscious of the team members and worked with us to achieve our potentials in the department.  There was always opportunities to cross train with other departments.
cons: some employees worked very long hours

pros: Big corporate, possibility to work with some of the greatest experts on the market. They will invest in your personal development and encourage you to take opportunity  of a huge array of courses to take part in if you wish to grow professionally. Faced paced challenging environment.
cons: Politics,politics and more politics. Training is scarce if not completely inexistent -the culture is very much a "figure it out by yourself culture"...you will need to rely heavily on a network of contacts in order to get the basic information needed to complete tasks. Two years before they will even consider a pay rise or promotion so make sure you negotiate pay properly before signing the contract.Beware your job spec will grow day by day.

review_title: Best Place for the Ambitious Young
pros: Good benefits and compensation, opportunity to learn and advance career. Very entrepreneurial. This is really a global company with a very local feeling. The workforce is pretty young compared to other places i have observed which means the company is in tune with the coming generation. The good side about DB is that if you work hard and long, you get very paid and recognized for such efforts. Be warned, this is not a place you can hide. If you are bad at what you do, you won't advance.
cons: Long working hours, no clear leadership structure, and very independent work environment which has its pros and cons. Personally i like these downsides.

review_title: Deutsche Bank is made up of many seperate businesses. In the GBS/GTO morale in 2011 is diminishing
pros:
Diversity of workforce
Compensation
Global mandate, breadth of coverage
Depth of responsibility
cons:
The GBS/GTO Division Operating Model vision is focussed firmly on cost reduction - it's execution of this strategy is aggressive
Multiple / frequent management changes create lack of continuity
Mentality of some key players can be political versus practical - seemingly this is rewarded
Having been at the firm for 10+ years I am delighted with the career development DB has provided me with - I would not however recommend DB as an employer of choice now, in 2011

review_title: Used to be a great place to work, but front office opportunities are dramatically worse now
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Very entrepreneurial culture where one is given a lot of latitude of what can be done. Very smart coworkers. Great graduate training program.
cons: They seem to be hiring more and more compliance people by the hundreds, to the point where getting anything approved is a challenge. The red tape makes working here more and more difficult. The pay/bonuses have been dramatically reduced over the last few years to the point where it makes no sense to work here.

review_title: Great graduate program and training, high compensation, good culture and benefits, uncertainty surrounding firm
job_title: Investment Banking Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Great graduate training program that included global training in London which made a seamless transition from undergrad to the workforce, banking compensation is high on par with other banks, new 2 year A-to-A program, great 401k plan with employer contributions, global and diverse workforce makes for a great firm culture, lots of firm and group events
cons: Uncertainty relating to overall firm as well as US investment banking strategy, extensive negative news headlines dampen employe morale, 24/7 work culture, technology is subpar and in need of substantial investment to reduce lost productivity

review_title: Deutsche Bank - a typical investment bank
job_title: Associate, Global Markets in New York, NY
pros: If you are lucky to have a good manager, the sky is the limit. Very enterpreneurial place. Lots of emphasis is placed on learning and training. For new associates, the first 3 months spent in training and 3 in rotations, which is really helpful as it gives one an opportunity to be introduced to various parts of the business. If you are ambtitious, driven, hard-working and willing to sacrifice your personal life for a career at least for a certain period of time, this is the place for you. Many intelligent people so one can learn a lot from them.
cons: Very hard to switch groups, so if you are unhappy, you're pretty much stuck.

review_title: I miss working for Deutsche Bank
job_title: Junior Research Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
DB was the most organized out of all of the companies I worked for. They keep up with the times, treat their employees well and there is a lot of opportunity to grow if you're the type of employee who puts 100% of yourself into your career and have something to offer.
They actually use the 5-point plan. They didn't just roll it out and work around it. It proved to be very effective. They utilized all of my skill set and challenged me to grow.
cons: DB is very competitive with talent and you really have to know how to negotiate for the salary you want. Smart on their side, but difficult if you don't know how to negotiate a good compensation package.

review_title: Large organisation with some excellent but also at times average employees
pros:
Global powerhouse that has some truly exceptional talent. 
Work-life balance will vary depending on your division/team. For front office function expect 12 hour average working days. 
Top level leadership on the whole appears to have the right intentions but success of implementation remains uncertain. 
From experience DB typically will give young talent the chance to shine.
cons:
Despite many of years of integration efforts, teams remain siloed in comparison to other banks. 
- Inter team moves can be extremely challenging (e.g. FX sales to rates trading) 
- Politics can get intense at more senior levels with disproportionate amount of time spent on internal negotiations.
- Some very aggressive individuals on the trading floor

Away from the siloes, rest of the "cons" are unlikely different to investment banks.

pros: I started as a graduate and worked in various strategy/ business development positions afterwards. As management changes the strategy at least every two years, there are interesting projects in strategy all the time. Most of the colleagues are great and it is fun working there. In most divisions working hours are moderate (normally not more than 10 hours a day).
cons:
As management changes it's strategy pretty often, the client is not at focus. They tried to change the corporate culture which did not (yet) work.
There are hugh differences in compensation between divisions (investment banking and the rest) and the older and younger employees. Compensation does - in many cases - not depend on performance.

review_title: Steep learning curve, changing and dynamic environment, on the forefront of change and evolution
job_title: Analyst in City of London, England
pros: Very professional, inspires growth and development, motivates personal growth, inspirational leaders, tools to excel are easily located. Self starter culture no hand holding which is good as it pushes you to drive yourself further. Amazing experience would love to return one day.
cons: If you are a temp you can only stay for maximum of 45 weeks until you have to be made perm or leave. Extensive screening - dig very deep and fill every single week gap you may have (took about 2weeks)

review_title: Good Company with Plenty of Problems Right Now (New York Office - 60 Wall Street)
job_title: Senior Applications Developer in New York, NY
pros: Traditionally conservative culture. Good technical level of majority of people. All range of products and technologies you can work with.
cons: Due to huge losses in Europe, they lost a lot of people for the last 4 years and the work load for the rest is unbearable now. The pressure increased dramaticallly where the working weeks in some IT groups (in my particular) was over 70 hours/ week including weekends. People are being treated much worst than it was several years ago.  Promisses of good bonuses currently is a lie, some departments such as structured securties lost a lot of good managers and is completely mismanaged.

review_title: If your in the Back Office operations and you have a silly manager, good luck to you poor fellow
pros: You get a very good exposure to various financial products/services. Have great client interactivity and within the organisation.
cons: Workload is too much, and if you are under a manager who does not recognise your capabilities rather recognises you for chatting him up, then you may not have a great career life in this organisation.

review_title: Very good, but could be better
job_title: Lead Applications Developer in Moscow, Moskva
pros:
Great corporate culture - you feel proud to be a part of company.
Office and working place of highest standard.
Great benefits package.
Competitive compensation level (at least by the time of hiring - see details in Cons)
International team and a lot of cutting-edge challenging problems to solve.
cons:
A lot depends on your direct management. And it's a matter of good chance to get one that will help you to implement your career potential.
Questionable employee retention policy - a company rather hire new employee than raise compensation for existing employee to the same level thus doing little to retain experienced worker.
Periodic serious organizational changes leave some good initiatives half-done.
Inertia due to various level of internal bureaucracy is high, which is quite natural for the companies of such size and level.

review_title: Enormous amount of work, limited advancement
pros: Lot of work, large scale projects in the pipeline. Potential to learn a lot. LArge focus on people esp. within the smaller locations.  Power center is in London, NY and Frankfurt, so try to be in one of these locations (esp. at the VP and above leve;l). Lot of lateral movement of people.
cons:
Complete focus on costs.  No promotions above VP possible without significant fat-letting. Fragmented organization with personal fiefdoms.  Internal costs have skyrocketed esp. in tech where the duplication of functions across IT groups means that your job is done twice and then checked.  
Recent oeprational excellence had created confusion in the ranks.

review_title: Overall a good place to work, good experience.
job_title: Assistant Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Strong, solid company.  Many opportunities within.
cons: It really matters which group you work for.  Some groups are very disconnected from the positive culture DB tries to instill.  I went through many different departments; my review would be much more negative, if I would not find a different opportunity (within the company).

job_title: Vice President, Human Resources in New York, NY
pros:
Great people
Space to shape your own role
Flexibility to do things our own way
Diversity of individuals, not a "clone copy" of one another
Very global thinking and acting
International opportunites
Career mobility if you manage it yourself
Survived the market crash well
Pretty good pay compared to some competitors
cons:
Disorganised
Slow decision making
Not a meritocracy - promotions and pay are political
Pay not linked to performance
Poor senior leadership
Our of date technology and processes
Short term initiatives rather than long term strategies

pros: Great benefits as an American employee; probably the best at a bulge bracket firm. Additionally, at least in the Jacksonville office, a very reasonable work-life balance. If an attorney, the bank will cover bar dues and continuing education costs.
cons: Entering into the bank at a time of severe financial difficultly has imposed restraints in both upward and lateral mobility. Compensation is at the lower end of the industry standard, and the Bank is reluctant to provide compliance officers with continuing education (Series licenses; CFA; etc). Working in the nearshore office comes across as a decision negatively impacting career growth opportunities.

review_title: Deutsche Bank is a pretty good place to work
job_title: VP, Engineering in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Stable, high salaries, fast-paced. It is a large company so lots of opportunity to move around.  Good perks such as 401k matching, pension, vacation days, free museum access, etc. There's a surprising amount of independance of how to solve problems here.
cons: It can be beurocratic and slow-to-act. Management ability varies widly.  Deutsche Bank's corporate culture, at least in the New York region, was to be cowboys - we were encouraged to do whatever possible to get the job done as soon as possible. Later, after the Bankers' Trust/Alex Brown acquisition there was too much process. Only now are we starting to get a good balance.

review_title: DB is a wonderful place to work
job_title: Assistant Vice President  in City of London, England
pros: Progression is on merit which is wonderful if you're good at what you do, also being able to move between divisions / offices is great. Personnally I have loved every minute of being at DB (currently for 5 years) and would recommend the bank to others. Hard work is required but hours are not as insane as other banks I have worked for (namely a large american one!)
cons: Political environment and slow to get action quickly. PMO activity is limited to manager feedback only where I feel a full 360 review is a lot more beneficial to the overall picture.

review_title: You will find yourself working late hours in a very employee unfriendly environment so I cannot recommend DB.
job_title: Hedge Fund Administrator in Carlsbad, CA
pros:
- Some positions give you the opportunity to travel.  Deutsche Bank has office locations in many countries across the globe.
- Typical large company benefits. Medical, Dental, Vision
- 3-4 weeks paid vacation, depending on position.
cons:
-  You are expected to work very late hours.  Not very work - life balance friendly.
-  Salary adjustments and promotions given once a year across the entire bank. No exceptions.
-  Very strict compliance department. You must move all bank, 401k, IRA, etc accounts into Deutsche Bank accounts.
-  Upper management spends needlessly and is not efficient at controlling costs
-  Not employee friendly and management is terribly inefficient.
-  Staff is not rewarded or given credit for hard work / Your performance is not linked to your salary

review_title: Nice place to work for Entry-level careers
pros:
The benefits are outstanding, medical, dental, vision, and vacation days. Interacting and meeting new people from around the world is very interesting and a great learning experience. 
This is a good career for an entry level position, in the finance industry and also if you want to gain experience.
cons:
The pay is not good, for the workload and the expectations that is put on our plates. Loads of pressure to be perfect not humans.
Outsourcing is a huge issue. Saving money does not always ensure quality for the clients. Duh!
Extremely high turnover, which should cause a light bulb to go off to upper management.

pros: Good health insurance and one of the best pension benefits 15% of your salary once you're over 30 or reach Associate level. Growing presence in Ireland
cons: Lack of technical skills, management keen to take on work from overseas offices without the prerequisite technical knowledge of the work necessary to maintain levels of service for clients (service centre mentality focused on keeping costs low, growth based on outsourcing from abroad). The office needs to develop clear employee development and progression paths in order to retain talent. Salaries at the lower end of the industry

review_title: Depending on the division, can be exciting but lack of stability makes it hard to establish yourself (mid-senior level)
pros:
- A truly diverse workplace
- Reasonably meritocratic: base salary roughly in line with industry average, but salary can bump up your total comp if you do a good job
- Better work-life balance compared to other banks
cons:
- Intransparent promotion process
- A lot of politics at D and MD level
- Serious lack of organisational stability, which makes staff feel very insecure and unsettled
- Very few female senior managers
- Town halls are very generic and not very meaningful
- Internal career mobility can be encouraged more

pros: The bank is generally involved in all the good deals/underwritings and seems to have the resources to be one of the best banks in Europe. I am optimistic about the new CEO and strategy, and see an effort on senior management's part to create a cultural change. Decent salaries. The potential sale of Postbank could make things a lot better.
cons: The IT systems are not good and result in some time wasting. The bank has in the past been good at creating strategies for short and mid terms horizons, but not so good at executing them.

pros: The money is/was good.  The bank is now trying hard to be a technology company, but not sure how successful it would be.
cons:
The bank had never been a technology company, and had heavily relied on its outsource partners.  However, in the recent months it is trying hard to be a technology company and trying to bring in expertise and intellectual property.  But in doing so, the culture within the bank has taken a back seat.  It is not the same place anymore.
Work life balance is taking a back seat.

job_title: Assistant Vice President, Applications Developer in Cary, NC
pros: Awesome benefits! Great pay! The Cary location is really investing in creating a community. There are employee engagement groups that work hard to make this a great place to work! I am working in cutting edge technologies and the company seems to want to invest in their employees and in employee retention. The office space is very nice including an onsite cafe and gym.
cons: There is less flexibility than in most tech companies I have worked for. At the Cary location, you can work from home on occasion, when necessary, but most people are in the office most days. It is a bank. As should be expected, there are security and process requirements that can impede your job efficiency.

review_title: Once great, struggling to resolve mass fragmentation caused by previous short-term strategies
pros: One of the most forward thinking and technically innovative banks of the early to mid 2000's with many hard working, intelligent and well meaning people.
cons: Corporate mentality of divide and conquer and to compete against and out-perform peers, as well as questionable re-organisation attempts has left the bank incredibly fragmented and unstable, from front to back office, technology and operations - particularly technology. The lack of governance will cost Deutsche Banks position as a tier 1 global contender.

job_title: Sales Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
Deutsche Bank itself is a top three investment bank and is a great resume builder
Benefits are great
Managing Directors and Management are accessible for questions and information 
Depending on business of broker you work with, job can be extremely diverse, high pressured, and a great challenge
cons:
Being  a Sales Associate is a dead end position, so make sure you love what you do and who you work with
Promotion within the firm from this role is difficult and not necessarily encouraged 
Brokers do not always respect the associate role and the amount of work actually involved.

review_title: Solid company with solid values and looks likely to ride out the storm!
pros:
Enjoyable work with a very good work-life balance. There are appreciative managers who understand how to get the best from their directs.
The bank looks to be progressively engaging in new technologies and pushing hard to maintain a lead with its banking platform.
There appears to be global opportunities and good career development for those who seek it.
cons:
Slow to move in new directions. Focus towards reducing risk going forwards is often seen to be paralysing and (in some cases) appears to be reducing the motivation of (some) staff.
A few too many clock-watchers and a few pieces of dead wood lying around the place, but generally these people don't seem to get in the way too often.

pros: Very intelligent and cooperative coworkers, more laid back atmosphere than the location on Wall St. Management is in general good at directing day to day activities.
cons: The Jax office is turning into an analyst churn shop. They are underpaying 2-3yr analysts and first year associates big time. In fact, brand new interns are making more on an adjusted basis than 3rd year analysts due to the company moving interns to the new higher pay scale while leaving existing employees on the older, lower scale.

review_title: Good and bad depending on who you are
pros:
Pay is fair to good for the sector
There are very good networks for families and other interests
Had a good corporate social responsibility side i.e. working for the homeless
You wont meet many stupid people (ignorant maybe but not stupid!). 
Standard benefits expected from an investment bank i.e good
cons:
Have to work hard and long hours
Be prepared to not talk to many people during the working day - some teams don't talk to each other..at all!!
Heavy bureaucracy and politics in some areas
Frequent occurrence of less able workers being promoted over more able workers
Who you know overrides meritocracy
Senior Management focus can sometimes be wrong and strange
Hardly any females or minorities at Senior Level

job_title: Assistant Vice President in London, England
pros:
Reasonable amount of autonomy. Some very good people. Some interesting projects and technology initiatives, although their scope is not always as widespread as you hope. 
Some confidence that John Cryan is the right person for a very difficult job. He seems honest and upfront.
cons:
Feels like everything is being cut back. Once had aspirations to be a top tier institution, now feels 2nd or 3rd rate. 
Senior management have changed so much in a short space of time which means there is a lot of review and validation of existing work. When will we get around to execution?

review_title: Great people, but plenty of bureaucracy
pros:
* People that make up the immediate software development teams are really great and friendly
* People are more than willing to share and teach skills
cons:
* Interactions with middle management can be frustrating. Mostly claiming that their "hands are tied" when it comes to suggestions
* Interactions between different departments can be challenging, and you have to navigate yourself through the different fiefdoms
* Plenty of paperwork and archaic processes to get many things done. 
* As the workforce gets smaller, there are more overworked people that you need to deal with when going through said paperwork and processes.

pros: Having worked in several different teams in Deutsche Bank in London I can honestly say that it is a very meritocratic environment.  Sure the hours can be long and there are difficult characters to deal with (that's banking!) but generally if you are good, and work hard, then you are rewarded.
cons: Nothing that couldn't also be said about other companies in the industry.   Deutsche does perhaps struggle with whether it wants to be a dynamic, flexible organisation vs being a company that dictates standards.  However the balance is better than another bank I have worked at where the fixation on process was bodering on becoming a liability.

review_title: Great place with a few flaws
pros:
--Great Pay
--Good vision by senior management
--Global presence
--Incredible place to start your career through their graduate program
--People with diverse backgrounds
--Business understands the value of technology
--Mobility encouraged and promoted
--Spends money for social causes
--Great benefits
--More vacation time than you can spend
cons:
--Senior management comes up with brilliant ideas, but picks morons to implement them
--Middle management (VP/Director) level is full of nasty politics
--Complete lack of diversity in upper management (mostly male and white)

review_title: Old School Company trying New School management style
pros:
Good pay and benefits.  Good people on staff.  
Good pay and benefits.  Good people on staff.  
Good pay and benefits.  Good people on staff.
cons: Getting things done with the rest of the bank in the rest of the world is very difficult and time consuming due to bureaucracy.  Management in Cary is under pressure to show that they can do things quicker and better than has been done in the past, but this is at odds with the rest of the bank in the rest of the world, which works at its own speed.  On another note, the environment is very noisy, which can sometimes make it hard to focus.

job_title: Quantitative Analyst in New York, NY
