pros: The atmosphere is good, the work is not so stressful, and is sometimes interesting. It is possible to learn a lot from this job.
cons: There are some problems in their infrastructure. It takes some effort to communicate between different divisions within the bank (front desks, risk management, and model validation) and the proprietary internal library can sometimes be hard to use and easy to err.

pros: Alot of the everyday  workers were really good and hard working.
cons: With over 5 years at the bank I was treated like crap towards the end. The manager's were more like bullies and tried to force you into doing things you should not have to do. If you voice a concern they try push you out. All the slogans and beliefs are just words and used to manipulate you into doing thing that are just wrong.

review_title: Horrible Management in Lower Levels that comes from Upper Management in New York
job_title: Client Lifecycle Management in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Good benefits,  nice office space
cons: You have to suck up to unprofessional local management in Jacksonville in order to “fit in” and be acknowledged.  Managers in Jacksonville seem to have two faces with one being used for upper management and a nasty one being used for direct reports.

review_title: It's still very much an old boys' network on Wall St, Despite having a women's network,
pros: It's a global firm and there's a great opportunity for international exposure.
cons: Smartsourcing/outsourcing has gone wild without consideration for the skill and talent levels that exist locally,  Sending jobs to lower cost locations makes sense but not at the dramatic levels being forced by senior management,

review_title: Excellent place to work - until you get let go due to downsizing.
job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits, people, use of technology  and nice work areas.  Very professional culture.  People I have worked with and worked for have been hard working, take their responsibilities seriously and expect others to act the same way.  Hard work is rewarded.
cons: No job security.  Title/years of service don't matter.  If they need to save money by reducing headcount, everybody's head is on the chopping block.  But I'm sure that is true everywhere.  Workload can be heavy.  I worked a lot of overtime just to keep up as an admin, analysts seemed to live there.

pros: -Global Bank with strong brand name
cons:
Management continues to retain & pay under-performing staff, and in doing so has not left enough money to pay and incentivize star performers.

Bonus caps, underpayment relative to other banks, and outrageous deferral structures means that DB will not be able to compete for talent.

DB is the only bank which has failed to make any effort to improve lifestyle for employees or even acknowledge the issue.

Summary: You will get paid more at all levels at any other major bank. Business is declining precipitously and morale is extremely low.

pros:
Nice office, although I personally have never found the time to use the play rooms.
Various training programs, although these are available only after 6 months of employment.
Work for home option - 4 days a month.
Free & good coffee and tea.
cons:
Low technical knowledge level in most of the teams.
Organizational chaos - roles and responsibilities are not always clear. Often ended up doing lower level tasks than what was described in the role description.
A lot of waste in the so-called “agile” projects.
No mechanism to share feedback on your direct line manager’s performance.
Long working hours, including weekend, in some projects.

review_title: Hollow shell of what once was
pros:
1. Smart people but mainly from other banks
2. Good work culture depending on the department
cons:
1. Rife with bureaucracy

2. Bad systems leading to frustrations and not what you would expect from a global bank

3. Management is generally good however there are sporadic instances of incompetent managers who only have themselves in mind.

job_title: Business Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Flexibility in your work situation and remote access is great.  Many colleagues work from home at least one day per week-this is great for working parents.  There are many great programs relating to cultural diversity that promote and enhance a very inclusive environment for staff.
cons: DB has the potential to be an exceptional environment for real growth and development, however there is way to go before that becomes a reality.  Current management changes, ongoing upheaval and outsourcing makes this difficult. This puts undue stress on staff who are looking for guidance and direction.

review_title: A way too much politics in NYC office.
job_title: Relationship Manager in New York, NY
pros: to gain global experience in your area of work and work with multiple teams globally
cons:
-Bad management overall in NYC (not qualified for work at all) and nothing is being done by the senior management
-HR does not support employees. Most of HR reps are external to the bank and don't want to get involve in anything
-Old, difficult systems and processes to navigate
-A way too much politics in NY office. It is expected to have politics everywhere, but DB NY politics can be champions in it if nothing else

review_title: Not a technology organization in India at the least and there is no scope for career growth or advancement of skills;
pros: Global Organization, Great Market forray, Technology focused for Systems and Processes
cons: Highly Bureaucratic, most management is technology illiterate, technologist are just preferred for adhoc tech help not for working on strategic long term goals of systems , life cycles and their data and load thresholds

review_title: good to be in, hard to grow out
pros: good people, lots of opportunities to take on (if you dare), open-door style of Moscow dev center management, medical insurance and other perks. And many growth opportunities, but growth is slow.
cons: very-very-very slow changes, terrible change management of Bank in overall, illusionary long-term planning, domain architects changed every 1-2 years.

review_title: A blend of fun with corporate politics
pros:
Jaipur centre is great place to be with engagement activities compared to Bangalore

Good company to start with for beginners with opportunities to learn

Perception driven environment you hold foot in the organization no looking back

Great salaries and bonus at management's discretion
cons:
Big time corporate politics where HR and leadership is blind to the  situation

Old fashioned assessment process for promotion where results not shared. Difficult to grow unless supported

Over empowerment to female employees being taken adversely to harass management

review_title: Career development paralysed for the foreseeable future
pros: International exposure & in the past a great many collegiate & talented colleagues all pulling in the same direction.
cons:
Senior management have buried their heads in the sand for too many years regarding the cost challenge that the business continues to face. Forced in the last couple of years (quite rightly) by John Cryan & shareholders to finally tackle this issue the (unfortunately) necessary restructures have been managed very badly. Senior management in some divisions have made short term panicked decisions ultimately prioritising saving themselves & favourite senior long servers (high cost employees in high cost locations). They have made lower cost mid to junior level employees redundant or just moved “deckchairs around on the deck of the Titanic”. Many have not made decisions based on robust business reasons. In some isolated examples it has been worse still. I have seen examples of  totally unethically miss managing people & making the environment so toxic that people have left of their own accord nearly broken.
This of course has failed to tackle the cost challenge and has resulted in multiple badly managed rounds of redundancies within months in the same areas. This has left moral very low for those left and has blocked career paths for years to come. This does not set the bank up for success and will drive down moral further over the medium to long term. 
COOs are in the main unskilled in their field and have little understanding, control or governance in their areas. There is no sign of this improving, only more responsibility being delegated to already failing individuals.
HR are being “dumbed down” to administrators & processors with strong capable people leaving this department in large numbers in the last 18 months.
These two issues (COO & HR combined) mean that management do not have capable or trusted advisors & are also not challenged to make short, medium AND long term cost decisions whilst restructuring by humanely exiting the right mix of people to allow the business to rebuild sustainably.

review_title: Upper Management is inconsistent (or lacking in vision); reliance on the young and abusing H1-B
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Cary, NC
pros:
Great benefits
Fairly fast advancement for entry/low-level employees
Strong support for diversity (nationality, gender, LGBT...)
cons:
Inconsistent upper-management decisions/vision (layoffs quickly followed by panic hiring)
Lack of advancement for those at the Assistant Vice President level
Overuse/Abuse H1-B visas system
Have to leave company to advance salary/title for more than low level employees
Under-appreciation in the tech divisions for Financial Analysts
Extremely tight cost controls, including late year changes to vacation benefits 
Cramped and noisy working enviroment
Tech workers given "virtual desktops"-machines
Upper management extremely late to handle prior ethical lapses
HR represents the company, and does little for the employee

job_title: Summer Analyst in Frankfurt am Main
pros: The Deutsche Bank is a company with a truly global presence and as such it is very international even in Frankfurt am Main. Also, it offers good opportunities to advance on your career within the company. Also, having DB on your Curriculum Vitae after an internship makes at least the German employers drool.
cons: The working hours are sometimes pretty long, plus it has a somewhat bad reputation as a company in Germany, so you sometimes get into discussions about people who are motivated to express their opinion about DB. I also think that their recruiters really stand out with their somewhat bloated jargon.

review_title: Overall a good place to work
pros: Great pay, stable company, has performed relatively well in the global crisis. High caliber people.  Deutsche Bank treats its people well and is committed to providing work-life balance, where possible.
cons: Stodgy German culture, difficult to make changes, global nature of the firm sometimes difficult to negotiate. Management are under enormous pressure to cut costs, and mange one quarter at a time, making long term investment in infrastructure difficult.  Good people are let go to cut costs and then have to be replaced at a later date.

job_title: Vice President in Jersey City, NJ
pros: They usually try to do the right thing (the trading scandals aside).  The company is progressive.  If you end up in a good niche in the company, you can learn a lot and benefit in your career.
cons: It is a troubled institution right now and not a very fun place to work.  There are not a lot of good managers, just individuals who worked their way up the ladder through outlasting other employees.

job_title: Applications Support Analyst in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Huge amount of diversity and great acceptance of others. They have great benefits and the salary is at least on par if not better in most cases. Free coffee.
cons: It's an investment bank and it's all about the money. Can be very stressful. Training is usually lacking or non existent. Expectations can be unreasonable by management but there is always someone willing to point the finger in times of trouble.

job_title: Vice President Heaf of Human Resources Solutions in Manila, Manila
pros: Working in DB is great because I got to work with really smart and brilliant professionals. Its current CEO John Cryan maintains regular communication with employeess with high degree of sincerity. There is a strong sense of empowerment and employees are given the opportunity to pursue creative solutions to problems and seek career progression.  DB also invests significantly in employee's professional and personal development.
cons: DB still needs to work on improving systems integration to achieve its desired operational efficiencies.

pros: Great people, good base pay, diverse culture, engaged employee resource groups
cons: No bonus, poor technology/infrastructure, poor management, lack of communication, too long to make decisions

pros:
competitive remuneration, especially for new joiners
It once was a very strong and proud player in the Australian market
cons:
The bank globally is in very tough times, share price has tanked.
Below VP level there is very little bonus inventive - capped at 3-4% across the board and not reflective of individual performance
Promotion is next to impossible - usually a 2-3 year process and very unlikely in Australia
Australian franchise is downsizing resulting in poor culture and low morale
Year on year reduction on total compensation - expected to do more with less.
There is often a large salary disparity between people doing the same role.
Poor senior leadership - usually too interested in managing their own career rather than looking after their employees

pros: Diverse, detailed processes, great brand name, understanding the current organisational context, doing well in recessionary times, continously challenging the status quo, gives challenging assignments, opportunities in your home country as well as abroad, very subject matter expertise oriented
cons: Risk averse and bureucratic in certain situations, as it is very sme oriented it is a very silo fdriven organisation with matrix reporting, hence employees are not very sure of the reporting lines and sometimes managers are also not very sure as to how to deal with their subordinates as they feel they do not have the requisite authority.

review_title: You will enjoy working with DB
pros: Deutsche Bank is a slow-growing bank, however, it has its own strategy to keep the strong market and financial positions in the market. you will enjoy  and learn something from working inside. Meanwhile, the working environment is quite political, if you want to further develop you personal skills and control capabilities, DB is a place you should go for. The key point is that you need to speak out and be independent thinking.
cons: So called " German mind set", very process oriented organization. you should be prepared to spend a lot of time in meetings and different engagements. so, don't let yourself be lost in the busy routine and keep focusing on the valuable measures.

review_title: A frustrating place to work, but has been rewarding at times.
pros:
- It can vary but hours are usually fair
- Has still performed well despite the financial crisis
- Decent benefits 
- There are some very capable people in the Org.
- Attempts to embrace new ideas
cons:
- Hugely bureaucratic and complex organization to navigate, 
- Ineffective processes
- A unpractical IT organization with too many layers
- Far too many Program Managers not nearly enough people who do!
- Outsourcing gone mad!

review_title: Deutsche Bank experience is a true global banking experience.
pros:
1.) Global presence of the bank provides multiple opportunities for qualified individuals.
2.) Great opportunities to learn and great place to start your career.
3.) A professionally managed work environment.
4).) Good performance management system.
cons:
1.) Some amount of bureaucratic behavior is evident in administration.
2.) Organizational policies in developing countries does not match those in developed nations.
3.) Global career opportunities are limited to developed nations.Job opportunities in developed nations are not accessible/available for international employees from less developed nations.

review_title: Challenging projects and interesting technology slowed by bureaucracy and politics.
pros:
Great team atmosphere and focus on worklife balance.
Serious focus on agile and doing projects right.
Lots of OSS in use.
Challenging projects with notable impacts.
cons:
Antiquated technology (i.e. Win XP, IE)
Bureaucracy and resources are the hardest part of any IT project.
Politics of higher ups often subverts otherwise logical implementations, dilating project rollouts.

pros: Relatively stable company to work for (last major round of redundancies had happened a few years before I had joined). Good benefits (good health and pension cover). Decent bonus packages, especially if you happened to be a good performer. Good respected name to have on your CV.
cons: Highly political. Less than ideal place to work for if one wants to learn any new skills (especially in technology, where posturing and BS in industrial scale appeared to dominate the scene). It's possible to make a long-term career out of simply existing and doing very little, losing skills over time.

pros: Money, Money, Money  there can be a lot of money. Great people, and an exhilirating work environment. Would probably say that the bank is better than the competition in all respects: diversity, decent work/life balance for the S&Ts and even sometimes the IBers. transparency with management.
cons: difficult to move up and get foot in the door. There can be some subjectivity in the review process as elsewhere, but the downsides are significantly lower at DB. It can also be beureacratic at times with processes stifling business activity given the size of the bank.

review_title: Intelligent people, great bank, questionable outlook.
pros: Extremely bright people.  Enormous balance sheet and not afraid to take risk.  Tremendous international platform.  Many high quality professionals.
cons: Very difficult place to onboard as new employee.  You literally walk in the door and left to find your way - from getting your computer, right down to finding the Bloomberg technician for your install.  The talk is all about cross-selling product but the product silos are virtually impossible to overcome.  Systems are questionable at best; the firm still uses Lotus Notes as their e-mail exchange.  Bonuses were very poor this year.  After two years of momentum in building a great fixed income business, the risk of defections are high.

review_title: Looks Very Good From Outside Only
pros: Great Company for benefits. Global company so get to colloborate with employees from various countries. Opportunity to learn from a global prespective.
cons: Missing strong mid level managers. Hiring process can be based on who can recommend their own candidates and not completely on talent or professional background. One can get hired if you know the right people. Preference given mainly to local workforce only. Work experience is based on what team or domain you end up working with. Some teams are really great and some teams not so great.

review_title: IT: Very good with some natural drawbacks of a huge company
pros:
Speaking about Investment Banking IT (software development) only.
+ Good balance between innovation opportunity and proven solutions for the sake of stability
+ People professionalism
+ Attitude: almost always open, friendly, productive, result-oriented. Even if conflicts appear, it usually happens due to everyone's with to make the best they can but different ways.
+ Internal mobility opportunities. Both geografical and professional
cons:
A few drawbacks natural for a huge organization:
- Some good initiatives, changes may take ages to happen
- 'Global change' initiatives happen often, but come to result... let's say less often
- Sometimes too long management hierarchy make extra barriers
+ But there is always a way to overcome, if you really wish.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Mid-level professionals are quite talented and amicable.  Generally a stable place to work.  New management in Germany seems to be aware of many issues that have hurt the company in the past 5-6 years and may address some of the cons below.
cons: Poorly integrated IT systems.  US management is not given bottom line accountability and poor managers are rarely fired.  Heavy bureaucracy in Germany sometimes prevents things from moving forward elsewhere.  All this has resulted in missed opportunities.  Mid-level employees receive critiques from above and colleagues, but those above do not always receive feed back. Strong focus on fixed income could impact profitability.

pros: Base salary can be low but bonus can be really good.  The bank owns large systems and provides copious opportunities to learn and grow. The types of problems a big bank faces are numerous and always challenging.
cons: Poor hiring practices. Deadlines are everywhere due to regulations. London calls all the shots.  If you're not from London, growth potential is limited. US offices are shadowed greatly by the larger hub offices. Employees don't stay long.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: When this was Bankers Trust it was a great place to work. After "acquisition"  emphasis was placed squarely on the the managers to make money (which isn't a bad thing) but the way they went about it was wrong.
cons: No effort is made for the non-officer ranks. What you start at -- is generally what you end up as! The "team spirit" was replaced to a "us vs. them" mentality.

review_title: Challenging yet frustrating all in one
job_title: Human Resources Manager in City of London, England
pros: DB is a global force with many roles HQ'd out of NY or London, although Frankfurt does poke its nose on a fairly regular basis. If you're the right fit, lots of opportunities to travel internationally and has a robust training/appraisal system. Good bonus structure (HR/Reward department)
cons: Internal promotions can often be based on "jobs for the boys" rather than true merit, which can lead to frustration. Generally DB is seen as a stepping stone or lifer: you're either there for 3 or 4 years, or for 20+. Pay can be good at the outset but unless you're the chosen one(s), salary increments can be poor.

review_title: Global bank with opportunity to work in diverse business areas
job_title: Vice President in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Stable job environment. Lots of mobility options. Opportunities to work on new technology areas. Very good HR processes. Lot of communication from senior management through various forums and internal blogs. Opportunity to work with virtual teams spread across globe.
cons: Stagnant career growth(vertical/compensation) if planning to stay at same location. Too much  senior management overhead. Very difficulty to show results due to long and globally distributed management hierarchy. Performance bonus not typically linked to immediate achievements but more to business line and years with bank.

review_title: Started hopeful.  Good in parts.  Mostly disorganized, unsettled and political
pros:
Being a bulge bracket investment bank in an area evolved for technology and pharm companies means it pays far more than the local area.  There has been some progress where certain applications are now led from the center, but the majority is still "augmentation" with NYC and London calling the shots.  

If you like constant change, then this is the place for you.  Frequent reshuffles and changes in leadership happen, so you could see this as an opportunity if you can stick it out.   Deutsche Bank is undergoing a large scale refactoring akin to the Final Solution, jobs are being created in low-cost centers like Cary, so this creates opportunity.  Promotion is possible - Keep your eyes open and turn up then you will get promoted and receive a fat bonus

It is undergoing some changes to the building, the environment is spacious with lots of walls to put post-it notes on.  There is now more meeting rooms than people - which is good.

Lots of communication from senior managers at the beginning and end of year.

A great choice of food trucks for lunch.
cons:
Cary does "BAU" and stuff that is either not difficult or interesting enough for London to want it.  It is not a "Technology Center" or a "center of excellence" it's just cheaper than working in London and we get the work when London is downsized.

The CTC, as it is now known, underwent significant growth in 2013, then is retracting again in 2014 with a hire-freeze and mass firing.  As the other reviewer mention its is a flailing investment bank and it has recently woke up and realized it has too many people and it is not making enough money to keep them.  Don't worry though, if you can code it will be a long way to get to you.

Little communication from senior managers outside of the beginning and end of year.

Forced ranking.

The hiring process is bad... and you wondered why you stuck it out.  The recruitment team were often to blame but the HR team must accept the majority.  Escalate and make enough noise, then HR wakes up - but why then?  Most of us need jobs for our families.  Make sure you are financially stable and able to take the time out to be on boarded otherwise you will find it V. STRESSFUL.

Agile adoption has become comical.  Even if we wanted it; the external bank thinks it is developer jumbo that can be overridden if they shout loud enough.  They let the agile coaches go, so our walls are full of stagnant yellow notes, toolboxes of avatars and broken dreams.  The place is awash with QA engineers, Scrum Masters and Technical Program Managers.  Lots of managers.  Pretty much everyone apart from coders.

Our town halls are always long and contains announcements about tools.  We have never seen the tools.

Did I mention the politics?  It is sickening.  No matter how much they pay the sugar I still have a bad taste.

review_title: Not to be taken at face value...
job_title: Senior Associate Global Banking in London, England
pros: In the right team and setting, DB is likely a good part to work...still to be proven for me though
cons: Too political, back-stabbing and anti-meritocratic environment for anyone in their right mind to like and thrive in. Promotion and compensation seems to be more linked to how close you are to top management than any real ability to provide value to the business. Without there are some good and talented people in there, but in my experience their positive contribution was outweighed by the incompetence and ill will too many other. As you can hear I am less than impressed by DB compared to other Int'l banks I have been with.

pros: Young working environment that allows for a good work/private life balance. Management is very sensible to individual needs and supporting especially with junior colleagues.
cons: Tedious job, range of products is very limited compared to the entire DB potential, in some circumstances the management does not give the idea of being competent in specific areas. Promotions seem to be awarded based on age, merit is somewhat less relevant. Bonuses have only recently pushed up to market average.

review_title: Great opportunities, strong support from leadership to create world class, enterprise solutions.
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Cary, NC
pros: Deutsche Bank Global Technology is undergoing transformation to create new enterprise solutions on a global scale, and the Cary development center is a key component to this transformation.  This isn't a static environment with highly prescriptive roles. DBGT Cary has excellent opportunities for engineers that are driven, engaged, and supportive of change.
cons: Engineers that are looking for highly structured, pragmatic methodology will find the environment uncomfortable. Change means that everyone needs to reach beyond their comfort zone to ensure their success.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good extra curricular groups (if you get the approval to join)
cons:
Bad management (intolerable, inflexible no support)
No progression
Small yearly bonus
Micro Management
Poor work life balance
Inflexible
High turn over of staff
You are watched constantly, if you leave the desk for to long you're asked why.
Very Militant.

pros: Great name on your resume to get interviews. European culture that cares about work life balance.
cons: Once a great bank, currently managed by really lazy managers with really bad leadership skills. I joined as a graduate and had too much down time due to really inefficient process. I could easily pick people who are just playing the politics and doing nothing useful to the company. I was hired by a team and was told not to worry and just chill while the projects will get budgeted. Left for another employer and felt alive again. I realized I learned very little at this Bank.

job_title: AML Compliance Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Nice people. Flexible. Ok facilities.
cons: Poor management from top down. Promotion process is terrible. Pay and bonus way below par. Director recently compared pay to AIB BOI and other RETAIL banks. Miles off the mark. Expect way too much from you. Can never get their deadlines right. Always a panic. So many policy changes. Too many chiefs.

review_title: If you enjoy working as part of a team, this is not the place for you.
pros: The company's name on your CV carries a lot of weight. As a company, they are highly technical, and very good at what they do. One of the best houses on the street in terms of performance.
cons: The culture is geared towards individual success and achievement. The environment lacks a team work ethic, and as individuals the staff are not the most pleasant group of people I have worked with.

review_title: Stuffy work environment but with global possibilities
pros:
- Stable work environment
- Global outreach for personal development and career options
- Interesting people to work with
cons:
- Stifling work environment sometimes : pseudo innovation rewarded rather than actual improvements
- Lethargic on technology changes
- In India, DB has a very nepotistic and "arse-licky" culture, especially in the back offices

review_title: Sales Support  - Asset Management, limited opportunity for growth, ineffective departmental management
job_title: Sales Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Good work/life balance, rarely worked late or from home, opportunities to interact with senior investment professionals
cons: Fear-based culture, peers are afraid to point out errors or recommend process improvements, hard work is not rewarded, environment is too casual for those with a drive to succeed, co-workers strove to do as little work as possible and take short-cuts which was what our manager wanted as well. Lack of communication and apathy led to many errors. Not rewarding career-wise.

pros:
Work from home
Good working hours
Friendly people (at least in Global Technology)
cons:
HR does not build relationships with people
Lack of communication and transparency
Senior management and the bank as a whole not upholding to the agreed terms
Low pay compared to the tech industry or other banks
Career prospects are not very clear at the lower end of the spectrum and career advancement is pretty slow and not performance oriented (i.e. you have to wait in line for a promotion)

review_title: High Tech Labor Salvery.. too much bureaucracy.. too much panic all the time (Assistant VP)
pros:
It's situated in calm and peaceful Cary, NC
Bonus ( If you are are good in internal bureaucracy and manage to get it!)
cons:
In over 15 years of my IT career I have never seen such bad work atmosphere with so much panic and work pressure from chain of managers over you. Everybody is president , vice presidents and managers.. too less people who really work.. so of course work pressure... That's what managers are for right? Make tech slave labor work. or how else managers will get big bonuses?

Their new policy is to lure tech guys from other countries or other states to leave their good jobs dreaming big bonuses and peaceful life , come to this remote location of Cary...then make them work like slaves. Hire one senior tech guy and then hire four beginners so that this experienced guy will actually teach the beginners everything and even DO their job... as they are "no-vice".. so make sure you are not that "experienced guy"

This is not a bank. It's a bank's IT development center. So basically we develop applications for bank. So it works like a IT shop with all the crap that comes with it....

Every body ready to cut your throat to get anybody out of his bonus way. Everybody looks like in pressure and panic state.
If you are looking for great work atmosphere and peaceful life where you can work and do some innovative work then DON'T come to this Cary Development Center.
Only join this center , if you just want good pay and bonuses...but you should be ready to take this much stress, panic , and ready to be micro managed by omnipresent managers.

pros: Variety of work, can get involved in some really interesting types of contracts in different asset sectors and platforms, great experience, great people to work with and a lot of CSR / charity / social events to get involved with across the bank.
cons: Old (and various different overlapping systems for the legal department), no document management system, not enough legal administration support.

review_title: Good place to start a career
job_title: Operations Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Co-workers are generally friendly & intelligent and there are plenty of after work events.  Managers make themselves accessible.  New analyst training program in London is top notch and most expenses are paid.  Compensation compares well with most other banks (new ops analysts get overtime).  Good name recognition in the industry.  DB has been less affected by the financial crisis than many competitors.
cons: Jobs are being outsourced to lower cost locations (India).  Some people have tremendous egos.  Hours can be long.  There is limited mobility between the back and front office.  Wall Street office is nice, but the area gets lonely late at night.

job_title: Business Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Deutsche Bank provides excellent opportunities for professional growth based upon the opportunities presented from very early on.  Employees have the opportunity to prove themselves from very early on and take on a wide remit of work.
cons: In terms of career advancement and financial rewards for the level of work performed, this has not been entirely satisfactory.  It seems, as in most companies, the number of years of experience is given precedence over the level / complexity of work managed and projects successfully delivered.

review_title: Safe haven to hide and die as a specialist
pros:
Good compensation in comparison with other software companies
Possibility to have very little control over yourself if you play right.
Good people.
cons: Non result-oriented and highly political environment. People spend enormous amount of time on meaningless discussions. It is absolutely possible and widely encouraged to get promotions and salary increases just by feeding bulls..t to senior management. Many good specialists, who could otherwise deliver some value, figure this out and become highly paid politicians. Not to mention a wide layer of mediocre staff who just hide there doing nothing.

pros:
DB is a culturally diverse company.  In my opinion - management believes in the culture and values and it is expected that we all have a 'Passion to Perform'.
The company has no glass ceilings and growth to many different career paths.
The benefits package is awesome.
cons: My only complaint is about the organizational chart.  DB is a global organization but management is not always local - seeing the people you work with and work for would be really helpful.

pros: Good to see John Cryan trying to make some changes and a number of the senior management who broke the bank have been eliminated.
cons: Terrible culture. A number of old guard MDs still remain with their own empire building characteristics. A culture of blame. A culture of I will take credit for your work. A culture of I will rip as much money out of DB for me the manager and screw you the subordinate. A culture of bullying. As a woman, I left because my manager would scream at me in a public environment. He was an aggressive bully. Human Resources did nothing (because their bonus was paid by the bully). Avoid this employer at all costs, especially if you are female

pros: You're surrounded by extremely hard-working, ambitious, and intelligent people which really motivates you. The office in New York is on Wall St which is an iconic street and the building is beautiful.
cons: Although your salary is high, you will be working A LOT of over time and weekends and nights. In general if you divide the total number of hours you will be working and stressing and dividing it by your salary, you don't get paid that much.

review_title: Some improvements but still a long way to go...
pros:
- Some truly talented and driven people at AVP and VP level in particular 
- Very international 
- Strong franchise 
- Good opportunities to network outside your immediate area/division
cons:
- increasingly limited career progression 
- Intransparent and poorly managed promotion process in a highly hierarchical structure 
- Extremely poor quality of line managers seen at D and MD level
- Some of the toxic and bad behaviour still present across the bank, from front to back office
- Experience for employees too different from division to division: a lot of my friends benefit from flexible working arrangements eg working from home, but this is very much frowned upon in other parts of the bank

pros: Deutsche Bank is a great name brand to have on your CV.
cons: The Ireland/ East Point branch of DB is poorly managed. In one year, a team of 20 people that started together, 18 have left. All of this due to low morale and incompetent managers that devalue employees.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Bucharest, Bucuresti
pros:
+ Very competitive salary
+ Very good colleagues, brilliant people
cons:
- Many security trainings
- MANY security trainings
- Insane pressure
- Rigid company structure, organisational nightmare
- As a software developer; prepare to have 0 control, no admin right, have your activities monitored and no access to modern development tools unless you go through a tedious process of applying within the company
- Work-from-home only after having worked at the company for 3 months, and then only for max 1 day per week
- Very tough internal pressure to deliver, say goodbye to work-life balance

review_title: Enjoyed being an intern in trading...
job_title: Summer Analyst in New York, NY
pros: DB is a relatively young company in the Americas and is still growing, and has an atmosphere that encourages free thinking and innovation.  Management is very willing to communicate with interns (not sure about analysts/associates) as is everyone else at the firm.  People seem very congenial overall.  Training program is pretty good.
cons: Not all the people are completely competent.  Some seem to have been hired due to connections.  Also there is a fair amount of corporate bureaucracy, as is to be expected at a firm this size.

pros: People are human. They don't expect you to be a machine. People here have been very honest with me and I have had aggressive intellectual debates with my seniors without repercussions. People here are more laidback than people at other firms. There are many development activities here too.
cons: Not well respected on the Street. However, it is very respected in Europe. The IB outsourced research sucks. Sometimes, its easier to do stupid work yourself. Wish the MD had more contacts and got some more deals. Financial District is an ok place to work in but not a great place to live in.

review_title: It was OK, too bureaucratic and political for me.
pros: If you are a woman they give you a good amount of maternity leave. I'm not a woman, so that was not so helpful for me.
cons: They seem to make bad decisions about fire and hiring. The seem to get rid of the most expensive (and smartest) and replace them with someone cheaper.

review_title: Great place for working as software developer
pros: The friendly atmospehere. The great people working there. Some projects are very interesing and unique, you cannot find them in any other company in Russia. It's a great school for newcomers.
cons: There is a mobility opportunity to move to new team/project, but it's quite hard to make it. Office culture is not so good as it expected to be from such big company, but they are constatnly trying to build one.

pros: Great benefits and challenging work.  International company with opportunities for advancement and development.
cons: Work location in Jacksonville has grown over time, but the culture was changing for the negative.  Now that the site is running, there is an influx of internal employees from other locations globally (at a trememdous cost for relocation).  Those employees are tied to the old ways of doing things and less open to the familial atmosphere already created.

pros:
This company offers good benefits as well as a month of pay vacations plus 10 holidays. 
The bank is going through a transformation in which it is investing in technology to digitize the bank. As a developer is a very interesting moment to be in this company if you want to learn new technologies and get involved in green field projects.
cons:
The demand for new applications and tools is bigger than the people they have available at this point which ends up with heavy workloads for employees.
It is not easy to grow here, the policies to grow are very restrictive, also there are no increments in salary unless you move to the next  band.

review_title: A place with no ethical values and zero culture
pros: Good work life balance and nothing else
cons:
Back office for London, no real leadership required in Dublin, just follow whatever they ask to do from London.
The worse part is that there's no people culture: zero. The main motive is that everybody thinks for themselves with very little care for the team.
While I was there I witnessed several abused from directors towards other staff members, some quite serious, but, although complains were raised, nothing really happened.
The level of politics, especially from those in UK, is simply unsustainable and wears off after a few months. People tend to run away within 10/18 months.
The level of technology in use is very conservative, even if Dublin is supposed to be a center of excellence. The pace of technology adoption is embarrassingly slow.

review_title: A lot of opportunities - what happens with you depends only on you
pros: Very compfortable place to work. If you are smart or if you are stupid, if you are fast or slow-thinker - there is a lot of different tasks in DB, suitable for any employee. You can follow the tasks delegated to you. Or you can find new opportunities by your own and make them your project. Crazy mix of heavy bureaucracy and edge-tech startups.
cons:
a) If you will stuck in any "legacy" project - you will be lost in a swamp or you will fight to change existent environment.
b) All internal processes are incredible slow. However they work. Slowly, but work.

review_title: A good work environment, but weighed down by years of indecisiveness
pros: For me, a great team culture and not too high stress environment. It's a big German organisation, so comes with very good benefits. Was happy to come in each day and work.
cons: Progression is slow, both due to years of cost pressure, and also seems more time based than merit. Also years of mergers, spin-offs, CEOs, office locations - they are working their way out of a lot of bad past decisions. Makes it feel like an uphill battle to get things done sometimes.

pros: Great team environment, positive recognition of good work, challenging work and opportunity to grow / move into new areas, work with people across the globe on a daily basis in which you are able to gain great cultural exposure, overall a very positive experience!
cons: Communication across the bank is not always consistent, systems could be more user friendly and up to date, sharing knowledge and working across different business areas does not always go smoothly.  Probably facing similar problems to other bank/organizations of its size.

pros:
- Great progression opportunities
- Tons of roles at multiple locations worldwide
- Great exposure to a global audience via projects that span the whole globe
- Serious push from Senior Management to contribute in non-work activities - volunteering, challenges, charity work etc
- Good general day-to-day IT for staff usage (not to be confused with the shabby IT architecture)
- Good company benefits which doesn't cost a penny to a permanent employee
cons:
- Lower than expected pay. Equivalent pay in the market for my role is £5k more than what I'm paid here
- Poor work/life balance - none at all. May be this is just confined to the division I work in, but the house rules are from a bygone era - wearing ties; 5 days from office working; 9-6 hours; expected to sit at desk even when there aren't any tasks to do
- In addition to your day job, you are expected to do extra activities to be 'visible' to senior management - a subtle term for back kissing
- Senior managers have a separate office to other employees; seriously, I haven't seen such a set up since an 80s movie
- If your role doesn't require a mandatory course/leaning, it's very hard and onerous to persuade layers of management about a development opportunity, better off paying for it yourself
- There is hardly any 'tone from the top' messages. I am yet to be on invited to a session directly addressed by CEO or his direct reports

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Interesting and challenging work; great clients; broad global reach.   Despite Deutsche Bank's deep-rooted issues, pockets of strength remain among its rank and file.
cons: Horribly managed, awful morale, weak compensation and benefits, underperforming equity, antiquated IT, little to no perks.  Deutsche Bank's legacy ethical and legal issues continue to impair the company in nearly every aspect.  The good work of many employees has long been marred by illegal and unethical acts in a way that sr management has been resolve.  As a result, DB is uncompetitive from both an employee and customer standpoint.

review_title: Working in db is always challenging and exciting.
pros: Deutsche Bank Global Technology is undergoing transformation to create new enterprise solutions on a global scale, and the Cary development center is a key component to this transformation. This isn't a static environment with highly prescriptive roles. DBGT Cary has excellent opportunities for engineers that are driven, engaged, and supportive of change.
cons: Engineers that are looking for highly structured, pragmatic methodology will find the environment uncomfortable. Change means that everyone needs to reach beyond their comfort zone to ensure their success.

review_title: Decent place to work if you can cope with the politics. This place is about who you know, not what you know.
job_title: Sales Trader in City of London, England
pros: Decent pay, great offices, relaxed atmosphere most of the time, but hard working and professional
cons: the internal politics, the lack of senior managers admitting mistakes, and the gap in pay and promotion to a lot of people who deserve it to the people who tell the bosses they look great every day.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Moscow, Moskva
pros: Competitive salary, good med insurance, other benefits. Great corporate culture, nice office building, generally it's not hard to find interesting assignments or opportunities. You have to try quite hard to get a promotion, but personally I'm okay with that. You definitely don't need to work crazy hours for an advancement -- can be done in 40-50 hours weeks, if you really put your mind to it.
cons: Some processes are very formal thus, for instance, it takes a lot of time and effort to allocate any resource on a project

review_title: Good work environment with energetic and professional colleagues
pros: Excellent fellow staff; very well positioned site in the centre of Birmingham; good social life associated with work and the site managers made an effort to maintain the energy levels of the staff
cons: Treated too much like an external service provider to London by some of the senior managers in the bank, and not like part of the same company.  Too many senior managers in DB looking to blame others for major projects not being delivered rather than look for solutions.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Cary, NC
pros: The Cary, North Carolina physical plant is very nice. It is located right next to the Black Creek Greenway, a pleasant afternoon walk. Promised future renovations include a cafeteria and gym.
cons: They never do things right the first time. Middle management seems incapable of learning from its many failures. Senior management encourages middle management to blame subordinates instead of taking responsibility. The pervasive culture of blame means people spend more time and effort finger-pointing than actually doing work.

job_title: Senior Liquidity Risk Analyst in Berlin
pros: Scope of covered areas, really the top of the profession. Insight to the full operation of a universal bank. Some very well educated and respectful colleagues with the necessary drive.
cons:
- Salary way below the sectoral standard in the light of the experience needed for the job
- Life-Work balance non existant
- Annoyingly unserious career plans and compensation packages
- Many mistakes and delays due to bureaucracy

pros: Great benefits. Lots of talent to learn from and great middle management team.
cons: Too many changes from strategy to management.  High mobility rate causes lost knowledge and projects not implemented to the end due to multiple changes.

job_title: Software Development Engineer in Bucharest, Bucuresti
pros: Initial salary was competitive, colleagues were not the typical neckbearded programmers, there were some opportunities to work with some newer technologies, development work was decent
cons: A bit of chaos in the development area, colleagues were not so well prepared technically, salary increases don't keep up with the market, rigid corporate rules - you don't have admin rights on your machine as a developer, they promise you'll work both frontend and backend, but for me it was mostly frontend and I really didn't appreciate that

pros:
Structured
Senior managers mostly very competent
IT is improving
cons:
No investment in employee development
Very little room to move (up or laterally)
Not much collaboration across groups
Not very aggressive bonus scheme
Despite competency- time on job requirements prohibit promotion (saw a lot of brain drain in my brief stay there as a result). 
Narrow salary bands artificially suppress wages

review_title: Low end admin centric HR Function
pros: Regular coffee sessions at starbucks, drink sessions at CTC for the HR department where they.  indulge in gossip, chill during office hours...in the name of employee engagement. despite low/nil bonuses, fixed compensation of DB HR department is best in the market
cons: the new HR leadership has transformed the HR function into a low end admin function, all work is done by the HR COO team while the  HR business  advisors pose as mere  co ordinators. the new RPO (RECRUITMENT PROCESS OUTSOURCING) team from Allegis has not settled down well, even though Bank has spent several million dollars in onboarding them. All recruitment costs approved by HR independent of Hiring Managers, while no value addition has been shown by the new HR Target operating model.

pros: Performing your role felt like you always need to be on your toes so you always strive to be at your best. You also work with some of the best people in the industry who inspires you. Definitely a good place for people looking for personal and professional growth
cons: The work can be stressful and sometimes require long hours. May not be for people who think that work-life balance can only be achieved in an 8-hour job.

pros: Very good compensation. Young and professional people, ability to grow. Complex and challenging projects. The best company I ever worked for. Employee can get almost any training or conference. Your skills and attitude will be noticed. Your concerns will be heard. Of course it depends on your manager, but I never met a terrible one. If you smart you can always come to an agreement. You can change roles and projects easily.
cons: Terrible burocracy monster. Access to prod servers are managed by vendors, who are actually dumbs.  Not good life-work balance.

review_title: Great people to work with....but SMT needs a rehaul
pros: I worked with some of the smartest/talented individuals that were willing to share their knowledge.  We worked together to get the job done
cons: When it came time to "transform" the organization, it took to long for SMT to put a plan in place.  The rules changes frequently for my last 2 years there.  It left many with little confidence in the SMT.

review_title: Tough job in a tough environment
job_title: Investment Banking Analyst in New York, NY
pros: The clients and the deals we work on are quite nice. THere are many big names and headline making deals that make you feel part of the bigger wall street picture. Also the benefits such as healthcare and 401 K contributions are nice perks. Also good opportunities are available for global rotations as well as well as divisional cycles.
cons: Work is very time consuming and demanding. 70 hous work week is normal. Intense pressure from seniors who are sometimes actually quite rude and inconsiderate. Covert racism and discrimination prevalent within the bank. Also, not enough feedback and support provided.

review_title: Relatively strong equity research platform. Pay could be better, but good stability and work/life balance
job_title: Equity Research Associate in New York, NY
pros:
Work/life balance, face time is not big here
2-week mandatory time off for equity research folks is awesome
Good stability...layoff and mass cuts in the US less likely despite European troubles
Very good global network/resources
Mgmt is trying to bring more structure and resources
cons:
Pay is good when you first get here, but average to below average
Needs to do a better job of incentivizing employees
Needs more team events
No real sense of culture, siloed work environment
No good sense of what is going on in the business globally...lack of cohesion
Too many internal systems and they are old

review_title: Working in asset and wealth management
pros: Access to good credit facilities , world class research and good client entertainment eg frieze festival
cons: Far too many non client management making decisions , over burden of compliance , lack of investment in business

review_title: Be careful which division and team you choose to apply for.
pros: The bank is decent at recognizing high performers and promoting based on merit.  Depending on the group that you are in, work/life balance is achievable, however, if you are not working overtime you will not be seen as working hard enough.
cons: There is no singular corporate culture.  While this wouldn't necessarily be a bad thing, it results in vast inconsistencies in experience depending on which team, division, or even building you work in.  Unfortunately, if you find that you would like to transfer within the bank, management is able to prevent you from transferring for up to six months.

pros: It's a truly global bank with operations in practically all of the major markets.
cons: This could just be limited to specific divisions or areas, but there are a lot of incompetent managers. It appears that in an attempt to diversify the leadership (from a gender, not a race, perspective), the company hires and promotes incompetent people. Good leadership is desirable and respected, regardless of the gender, but it seems the push to 'market' its gender diversity has resulted in the company hiring people in high-profile positions who are truly not qualified or competent. People-management is both a skill and a talent.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Eat what you kill environment and if you play your cards correctly you can climb the ranks quicker than other sell side shops
cons: Tons of kissing up to the right people despite how good you are...nothing matters unless you cozy up to the right people. Some of the smartest people in the group never get promoted or paid since they can't play politics....

review_title: DB Centre on a Death Spiral
pros:
- Decent salary, esp for people from Tier 2 colleges
- Good work life balance if aligned to a chill desk 
- Some bright people here and there; but high attrition at junior levels
cons:
- C Grade Middle and Top Management in DBC 
- Extremely top heavy. Old timers are adding zero value and are clinging on for the lack of markatable skills - leading to near-zero attrition at top levels 
- Too much org politics
- Limited mobility within DBC mumbai and to other locations
- Skills you gain are usually not valued outside DBC or are not useful in Indian markets
- Back office culture and mindset
- Bright people have left already. DBC now consists of people who are finding it hard to get out

review_title: Pass the problem & blame culture. Not good flexible working/culture/diversity despite claims.
job_title: Assistant Vice President in London, England
pros: Some people are nice. Offices are ok. Benefits industry standard.
cons:
Some arrogant rude people.
Bonus is awful - always between 2-3% - never pay rises.
DB uses buzz words or phrases such as ‘work life balance’ ‘diversity’ ‘culture’ and ‘teamwork’ but executes very poorly. 
Have no money so single figures per department achieves promotion.

pros: None. This was hell on earth.
cons: There is a distinct lack of responsibility within the company. No one wants to take ownership, and I found that many people were confused about what they should be doing. People join and leave too quickly and no history of why is properly documented and no handoff of who is taking this over is captured (if anyone is even taking over). Additionally, the culture was abysmal. There is very little diversity. Resources are sparse. Better hold on to that pen they gave you the first day, because it's probably the only one you'll get. Hope you have your own hardware that is pared down enough to work with DB's sad tech.

job_title: Investment Banking Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Global firm name and reputation especially given current circumstances.  Foreign-based firms are probably relatively safer and "more stable" than their US counterparts.  This also translated to a greater diversity in the workplace.
cons: Office was very standard and no-frills.  Clear lack of team direction and togetherness with a very tight hierarchy adhered to.  This often translated to lack of motivation and a lot of time being wasted waiting for team members.  Lay-offs were also frequent and a lot of the work experience will revolve around which group you are being placed in, with some groups definitely having a stronger culture than others.

review_title: Not what I thought it would be.
job_title: Hedge Fund Administrator in Carlsbad, CA
pros: It's definitely a great place to learn about the hedge fund industry.
cons:
-The culture has changed overnight after the salary freeze for the coming year(s).  
-Nobody within the office really cares to go the extra mile anymore.  
-Compensation is poor compared to competitors in the industry.
-Management is decent at best; poor asset management as well as talent retention.
-Bonuses were minimal due to bad bets.

review_title: Good place to start your journey into the world of investment banking IT
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Moscow, Moskva
pros: Sometimes the work is challenging, good chance to see mature investment banking IT landscape.
cons: All important decisions are done in london and NY, management consider local devs as abstract resources, no recognition, a huge lot of legacy systems that nobody cares to clean up, everybody building something new (no incidents, always better then existing etc).

review_title: It is a fair company with great working culture and company structure
pros:
Fair working culture, prompting a great culture of informaiton sharing
Structure of environment, easy to find and to ask for information
In general, people are looking for long term relationship and professional in mind
Industrial leader of process control and internal audit standard
cons:

job_title: Vice President in Jersey City, NJ
pros:
Deutsche Bank is a truly global player, with a hugely diverse workfoce, financial products and opportunities. Exposure to numerous cultures, backgrounds and working methodologies means that any time here can contribute greatly to personal growth, your CV/Resume and career path. The working conditions are generally good, most people work reasonable hours and work/life balance is taken seriously by most managers. 

I think the benefits are competetive, internal training and learning is abundant and encouraged, and support for external education is good, as long as it is seen to benefit your current role. There is a process for internal movement, which works fairly well, especially when the market conditions are favourable.

Many of the more senior managers within the organisation are very talented and decisive. Once an initiative is kicked off, it's rarely done half heartedly. Strategic vision is well communicated and often executed regardless of resistance or pain.
cons:
Such a huge organisation is often riddled with confusing and sometimes unecessary beaurocracy - it's a truly 'German' bank in that sense. A one size fits all approach to process and strategy is sometimes unhelpful when trying to push through critical changes rapidly. 

There are also still too many middle-aged, unskilled employees, particularly in the US and Continental Europe (this is not the case in London or Asia-Pacific) who tend to be obstructive and miserable. Many of these have been pushed out via outsourcing, but too many remain in lower/middle management roles.

Compensation can range from being market-leading to insulting. If you stay much beyond 5 years, you're likely to fall very far behind the market and although this is probably true of many companies, at DB there is an almost complacent attitude towards this issue. It results in a brain-drain amongst the most dynamic middle-managers (VP/Director) especially if they have come up from Associate or AVP level at the bank. It also means the dead-wood I mentioned earlier are even less likely to be pushed out.

Finally the outsourcing of many roles lead to a collapse of moral in many parts of operations, especially in NY and London. Although much of the basic work is done outside of the high-cost locations, such as Bangalor and Mumbai in India, Birmingham in the UK and soon Jacksonville, FL, the real glue behind the work remains in the hands of a few over-worked and under-valued people who have stayed behind to pick up the peices.

job_title: Software Engineer in New York, NY
pros:

cons:
Few, if any, opportunities for upward mobility. You become eligible for promotion every two years. Because of stack ranking, you are unlikely to get a promotion, even if you have performed well. Performance reviews are based more on the visibility of the project you have been assigned and other useless optics, meaning that it often doesn't even matter if you go above-and-beyond and deliver a high quality solution.

review_title: Some glimmers of light, though Cary leadership leave little to be desired.
pros:
Contrary to the doom and gloom the media conveys about Deutsche Bank, the wider bank (external of the Cary office) is surprisingly interesting and there are a few nuggets of optimism.  With the recent senior management changes at board level, there are some glimmers of sense as the much needed rationalisation has happened in abundance - hopefully the target will soon be on the local Cary Director "leadership" as there is plenty of dead wood to strip there.

The working area is ok.  Somewhat like a call center instead of a development environment, which is kinda ok as not a huge amount of real development happens here.  Elbow room is in short supply, but this is compensated by the comedy of the center wide town halls which are a real hoot!
Deutsche Bank benefits are great.  Free holiday, pension, health-care and the work-life-balance of what is essentially an easy life make this an opportunity that is hard to overlook for anyone.  Second jobbing is entirely possible.
Bonuses went the way of the dodo a few years back and this resulted in a brain drain that made us a popular invite for any quiz-based social.  Gallows humor is common-place, which is a real positive, especially with the yearly cycle of musical chairs where we are often dumb-founded by the same near-misses year after year.
In the absence of old-style banking compensation, the balance of few promotions has swung to "promote anyone" this is good for the long-termers as there must be some corrections to be made, however it's a "Con" too (I'll describe below).
cons:
The nuggets of good I referred to as a positive are sadly not evident in Cary.  There are nuggets, just a different type, and this would nicely describe the local directorship.  The ego amongst the non-contributor population is often breathtaking.  Lots of references to "my guys", but little loyalty come compensation distribution and standing up to their higher achieving counterparts in the Financial Centers.
In reference to the "promote anyone" mentality, the quality requirement bar has dropped significantly.    Being a senior leader at Deutsche Bank use to really mean something with the MDs and Directors being some of the best in the game, now I would suggest they are operating at a minus one, as-in, MDs are the old Directors, Directors -> VPs and so-on.  Self awarding titles such as "President" for technology management with no apparent technology capability is demotivating for anyone with a technology aspiration.

pros:
Great flexibility in work-life balance. Working hours tend to be flexible, and employees are very accommodating to non-work commitments and activities. 

Great benefits. Health, dental, and vision plans are excellent. For a company in the US, there are lots of vacation days (over 4 weeks). 

Very good networking opportunities. There is a wealth of groups which do all kinds of fun activities. Groups meet regularly and it's an excellent way to get to know coworkers and make office connections.

The location. The Research Triangle Park area of North Carolina is a great area to live in.
cons:
Frustrating experience dealing with work computers and tech programs/tools. The computers are really locked down and it's often difficult to find the right tools for the job that aren't years out of date (I've seen this process improving, but slowly). There is little flexibility in choosing your tools for any particular technical task (it's not an option to install what you like). GitHub is blocked for most people.

Abundance of middle management. I've been on a team consisting of half managers and half workers. Certainly not every team is like this, and it's probably a result of being a large place.

There is a severe lack of technical knowledge among large amounts of employees (working in a software development environment). Many people aren't skilled enough to do their jobs well. One example: a manager on my team doesn't trust automated regression testing (they are not technically knowledgable about the development process) so even though we have a fully automated regression testing suite, people are required to *manually* test everything in releases before managers will approve the release, soaking up large amounts of time and resources. Knowledge of the basics should be expected, as it's a software development center. As a developer, is can be extremely frustrating to deal with so many people who don't know a thing about coding or development or computers at all, but are still supposed to work in a technical job.

Recognition and compensation is often largely tied to who you know, and less about how much of a difference you make. Of course, many people received what they deserved or even more, but for every person I know has been compensated/promoted fairly, I know another who was not at all compensated what they should have been. Over the years there were many senior executives that led Deutsche Bank, providing a strategic direction which never seemed to change - reduce expenses again and again.  Getting raises, bonuses and promotions was always difficult. Eventually, clients left and regulators questioned the lapses in controls, which lead numerous fines including $630 million for Laundering Russian Money, $2.5 billion for the U.S. and U.K. plus €725 million for Libor Interest Rate Scam, $258 million for Violation of US Economic Sanctions, $7.2 billion for the Sale of Toxic Securities Leading up to the Financial Crisis and $205 million for Violations of New York Banking Laws stemming from Foreign Exchange Trading Business.  The value of the stock declined from $150 in 2007 to the $8.00 neighborhood today.

When people ask me about The Big Short (2015) in reference to Deutsche Bank, I reply Independence Day (1996) is a more appropriate representation, where aliens came to take all available resources and wreak havoc before they move on to the next target.

job_title: Institutional Sales Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
Pros at DB include great work-life balance. The people are great; during my three year tenure I forged lifelong friendships with people I'll be in touch with for the rest of my life. Vacation days for those at the analyst/associate level can go up to 28 days for the full year, include rollover days, which is awesome! Fairly lax management who allows you to take the reigns without too much micromanagement. This obviously depends on the team, but I was on three different teams in three years and found that I was able to have free reign without too much pushback under the management I had to deal with.

Being able to have full access to the cafeteria in the basement as well as good La Colombe coffee across the street is also a nice perk. Everything you need is essentially within an arm's reach in FiDi.
cons:
Cons: pay is WELL below market value across front, back and middle office functions. People are generally jaded due to low P&L generation as well as less deal flow due to DB's recent reputation on the Street. Because of the aforementioned factors, DB is losing out on young talent rapidly because they are unable to compete with comparable offers other investment banks are giving to those who have decided to jump ship. Moreover, recruiters are actively reaching out to and poaching Deutsche employees due to the current state of the place. It's sad because in its hey-day, DB was probably one of the top European investment banks to work for and now everyone talks about it as though its a modern day Titanic. 

Senior managers are also being pushed out due to being too expensive. Even those higher-ups who do generate P&L have been let go because Deutsche simply cannot afford to keep them on payroll. Cost-cutting is the name of the game and it has sadly made for a very angry and frustrating work environment.

Lastly, Deutsche's infrastructure is so broken and bureaucratic it makes it virtually impossible for front office to generate new business. If a counterparty wants to set up a subaccount to trade a certain product with DB, the process takes weeks when it should only take 10 minutes. If an entirely new client wants to trade with us, forget it... that process can take months. Sometimes, by the time an account gets up and running to trade, the client is so disenchanted with our disorganized onboarding process that they decide the hassle isn't worth it.

Overall, I gained a lot of knowledge during my three years at DB. It was honestly an awesome place to start a career and build a decent nest egg, but if you're looking for A-grade comp at an uber competitive investment bank, look elsewhere as DB will only provide you with enough to get by and the place itself isn't terribly competitive because they can't afford to be.

Compensation was not bad as well. Rides home after 9pm, free meals, reimbursements on telephone bills, free Monday lunches. 

Overall, I really liked the people in my group. The compensation was another benefit
cons:
I feel that employee morale at Deutsche Bank has gotten to be pretty low. The perception, even among employees has been that Deutsche Bank has not performed as badly as its competitors throughout the credit crisis. This view was badly shaken with the mass lay-offs that have been occurring in recent months. Some of the blame lies with senior management who have not been forthcoming about communicating the extent of the problems within investment banking and about addressing the layoffs. In my group for example, when people were laid off, it almost seemed as if nothing happened. People even within the group refused to talk about what was going on and this just contributed towards the lack of communication that already existed. 

The hours in investment banking were also a killer. 100+ hour weeks were not uncommon. Furthermore, my group was plagued with the problem of "face-timing". Even if you had no work, you had to show that you were working at least until 11pm each night just to avoid getting ridiculous staffings for projects that some MD cooked up. 

The learning experience was not as great as I hoped it would be. People simply working on endless pitches with really interesting deals few and far between.

review_title: A company which is too large to be effectively managed but has a great brand
pros: The Deutsche Bank brand is brilliant - it is widely respected to DB's clients and because of this, it is also highly respected in the job markets.  The name on your CV, particularly if you can mention investment banking related experience, is worth a great deal.  In my opinion, the best reason to work for DB is it's global brand name.  Compared to other investment banks, its salary is competitive.  Another great reason to work for Deutsche Bank in the London office is the work life balance.  Unlike other investment banks, it understands that you have a life outside work!  For example, the social networks such as the family network are very active.
cons: Although Deutsche Bank boasts of a "one bank" culture, this is far from the truth.  The 1 bank brand is strong and it is worth recognising that there are roughly 80,000 employees at the firm; many of those work in the retail arm.  Although the retail business keeps things going in a downturn, it makes the firm far too large to manage.  Senior management is far too Germanic in their approach and fill your day with unproductive administration.  For example, technology and business audits are continually carried out but due to cost constraints, resourcing is so tight that there is no time to address these.  Some areas of the bank thrive but others consistently fail.

cons:
Compensation is exceptionally poor for people who work in technology. Bonuses are entirely politics based. It doesn't matter how hard you work. You might come up with a trading algorithm or technology enhancement that enables the trading desk to increase PnL by 50% to £1m, but don't expect that to be reflected in your bonus. You're still getting a fixed 20% so my best advice is to go home at 5 and not make the extra effort.

The business side still has absolute control over the budget, changing it widely from +/- 10% EACH quarter. It's impossible to plan any kind of stable headcount.

Management is poor. If you come up with a great idea in DB make sure you keep it to yourself, because EVERYONE will steal it and give you no credit whatsoever.

There are lots of opportunities in DB, but no one is going to help you take them. You've got to play political games all the time.

The graduate scheme is pretty awful. HR have made the assumption that if you're a graduate you know nothing about either banking or technology. I learnt nothing in the time I had training. You also get lumbered with two "Change Management" projects, which are essentially a load busy work and a waste of time. You teams management won't give you support in doing this so you're going to end up working weekends on it.

review_title: Great place to start, depending on your managers.
pros:
You can learn a lot of skills quickly if you put in your own effort. 

Most coworkers are friendly and supportive.

They'll hire just about anybody to do basic analyst roles (including former kindergarten teachers).

Good managers will watch out for you and give you clear assessments of your success and failures.

Depending on your role, you may have great work/life balance (40-42 hr/week) or you might work much longer hours regularly (45-55 hr/week).

Pretty easy to take days off.

Even with cons, it is still a worthwhile company, and has the potential to improve tremendously.

Depending on your role, it can be pretty relaxing.
cons:
Depending on your role, it can be very stressful.

The company is not kind to whistleblowers or people who raise legitimate issues with business practices and ethics.

Unsurprisingly, management and advancement is seniority-based, despite assertions that to the contrary of the environment being a 'meritocracy'. 

Horrific technology - they desperately need to update their technology. The current cost-cutting environment does not encourage investment in technology. It takes weeks to months to get access to systems. All employees have this problem, some worse than others. If you need new systems or applications, even critical ones, it still takes weeks or months.Tech support is labyrinthine. Submitting tickets to be updated is difficult, and most employees give up or put off fixes because of frustration with the system (most of the tech support is run out of Indian call centers, which is hit or miss - use local IT whenever possible).

The turnover here is high. Leaving the bank is on most people's minds, even if not said aloud. "Sinking ship" is a phrase used frequently used. The people who enjoy working here tend to feel that way because it is not as bad or stressful as other jobs in the banking industry (ex. Bank of America, Merrill-Lynch) or other industries (ex-military).

review_title: Very promising career path if you want to jumpstart into something exciting.

If you are going to weigh the cost and the benefit of you being in this bank, you might as well look for another opportunities - not a good company for a pay pocket.
